We had a meal a few nights earlier down the street at Wasabi which we loved. Our meal at Osaka? Half the price. Half the freshness. Half the service. Hafta leave. 

The Sashimi looked dull and old. The hot dishes were over sauced and salty. I also ordered Naguri which the server had to go back and pester the chefs at the sushi counter 3 times to get it made before our meal ended.  She really tried hard and all the wait staff was hustling. I would have rated one star if it weren't for our server.
author: Duane B.

description:
Went here for a special dinner. The restaurant was crowded and a bit noisy, but I didn't mind that too much. The service was very attentive. We had bento boxes for dinner. The teriyaki chicken is alright. The tempura vegetables were exceptionally fresh.

Prices are a bit high but not entirely unreasonable.
author: Michael E.

description:
Small little Sushi place, but they offered some really creative options. I honestly had a hard time deciding what to eat (unusual for me). I wish I had gone with more people so I could have tried more. I ended up with the Castro Roll from their specialty roll section. I thought it was really good and fresh.

The sake was less impressive, but I'm not an expert in that area. I selected the only "sweet" sake offered on the menu, but didn't find it sweet at all.
author: Jacob P.

description:
Service = okay.

Prices = expensive on regular menu. I only ordered off the Happy Hour menu... three 6-pc rolls... one veggie handroll and small bowl of piping hot udon..under $20.00!  

Sushi = okay.... Uhm this is IMPORTANT...use good quality produce...vegetables! (Not just the fish). My rolls tasted a bit funny, and at first I thought it was the fish, but it was because the avocado was bad. :( and it left a funny taste....boooo! 

Limited seating....small place.
author: Fannie S.

description:
We've eaten at Osaka about a million times over the years, and I have to say it's a hard review to write. There seems to have been recent turnover in staff, so for the past year we've experienced kinda iffy service. Capable, but pretty standoffish. Our last visit happened to coincide with a Giants game, so we (politely) asked if they could put the game on instead of the ESPN news channel or whatever it was. The waitress asked what channel the game was on then made some excuse to stall for time. Eventually she asked the sushi chef to change, once we explained what channel it was on. Yeesh, this is becoming one of those annoying Yelp reviews, isn't it? Serves us right because the Giants plotzed anyway, we should have let them leave it on NASCAR coverage.

The real reason for the three star rating is that nowadays I'd say they're 4 stars at happy hour, when most normal sushi rolls are in the $4 range (we ate six rolls, edamame and gyoza for $33). At regular prices, you're knocking on $50+, and by that time you should just walk the couple blocks over to Amasia Hide's, where the sushi will cost about the same but be of much higher quality and the seaweed salad is superior by far.

Be sure to check the signs around the walls and the specials list. The menu seems to lack some of the typical non-sushi Japanese stuff, but some of these wall signs let you know that you can get some of them (I saw a sign for tonkatsu, for example). Also, there's a sauteed mushroom appetizer that is just fantastic. I didn't notice it on the menu yesterday, but if it's still there it's really worth adding to your order. A nice complement to the typical sushi joint fare.
author: Spaulding A.

description:
"I know a sushi place in the Castro and it was pretty good."

I don't know why I take anyone else's sushi recommendations. Really I don't. They always end up being too expensive, or bad and I leave with a glare in my eye and itchy fingers to Yelp the crap out of them.

I like my Spider roll to taste fresh. I like it to be large. Some call me a sizest. I call myself picky.

I like my miso to be hot and I like my avocado rolls to not be 50 percent rice. And I like this all for a decent if not fabulous price. You don't have to be Berkeley priced, but I expect some moral high ground to not shaft me so hard I feel it in my sleep.

Osaka, your miso was good, your Spider roll was unpleasant and you do the long booth thing I hate. But the boy liked your food.

Feel lucky.
author: Meg T.

description: Not the most amazing Japanese food in the world but it's decent enough. I say this because if I had to rate all of the Japanese restaurants such as this one, they would all have three stars. It's nothing special but like I said it's decent enough. The menu is pretty cliché. You have the typical Kathy, spicy tuna rolls, bento boxes, and grilled food. The service isn't too bad. Although I did have to move to another table because of bunch of millennial's had six people, and I was annoyed by the fact they were all on their cell phones. But that's besides the point.
author: Vinson H.

description: I like the food and it's a good time and all BUT, the service isn't all that great.  There was like one server for the whole restaurant.  I constantly had to ask for something.  Sometimes it's great and sometimes not so much.  If the service was on point, I'd give it 5 stars.
author: Shaun W.

description: Salmon hand roll and avocado roll was delicious. Chicken teriyaki was disappointing,  tasted bland and the sauce was watery.  Calamari katsu was ok.  Service was average.
author: Nina C.

description: As always delicious!!!!! Perfect mix of flavors in every roll we had. Except the spider is a little weird with too much lettuce. No point off though..:-). Love that Pink Lady roll and have it every time...so good! Yes I come here a lot.
author: Matthew F.

description: I ordered a few very standard and easy things including california roll. sadly nothing was very good. I am not someone who is really picky about sushi, but this just wasn't very fresh.
author: Little B.

description: Good food. HORRIBLE service. Our waiter walked away twice while we were ordering as if we weren't talking. Then they had the nerve to add a 20% tip for a party of 4. What?!  FOUR?!  We each ordered one dish and never saw him again. Really?? Never again.
author: Charlie A.

description:
I enjoyed osaka sushi very much. I had god company and good food. Service was a 5 star, food was a 3.5 and price was 3

Though the sushi was good and the fish was fresh it was not 100% spot on or amazing and fantastic to get a 5 star review. I had the mis soup which was good an excellent seaweed salad as well as a little better than average rainbow roll. The tea, if you like asian teas, was good hot and served plentifully.

Service was very good. Server was quick and the sushi chef was right next to us to help us find an old roll we had once. They forgot to give me my rice I ordered, which was fine since i was perfectly full already, they were very apologetic and took it right off the bill and were very prompt to brining the bill back. They also all greeted us as we entered and even as we left leaving a very nice impression of the place.

Synopsis: If you want good food, excellent service, and a all around nice experience, i would highly recommend it for a nice date or if you have a hankering for good sushi
author: Peter A.

description:
I LOVE happy hour food. Osaka has a HH, everyday from 4-6PM!

Their happy hour menu is split into a couple price groups, you can choose from about 4-6 different dishes in each with prices ranging from $2.95-$6.95. If you're looking for a cheap quick bite this is definitely a great place to go to. Service has always been exceptional for me.
author: Av A.

description:
If you are looking for sushi (nigiri/sashimi/hand rolls/etc.) please save your money and go elsewhere. The fish has little to no flavor, unagi came cold and could only taste the paste, and the hand rolls (spicy tuna and spicy salmon) had no flavor, seemed to be just a similar paste and the seaweed was chewy and stale.
The specialty rolls fared a little bit better and the rest of the group were OK with their Bento boxes.
Loud club music in addition to the high prices made sure that we won't be back.
author: Big H.

description:
From the outside, it doesn't stand out, but wow I've been here soooo many times now I couldn't believe it! I think the same owner who owns Barracuda owns this place also. Totally different vibes - Barracuda is more modern and trendy while Osaka is definitely more homey like a traditional Japanese restaurant. 

What first attracted me here was the happy hour menu that was decent. Happy hour here and eat something, then move on next door for more happy hour drinks. A perfect way to enjoy the evening. Sometimes I come here to eat after a night of drinking - I don't usually stay out late much, so them closing at 11pm works out perfect for me. 

The sushi chefs seem to actually be Japanese which is a big plus for me. The Crazy Roll is probably my favorite here, though pretty much all the rolls are a pretty large portion. The bento dinner is somewhat on the expensive side, but it's prime location and only steps away from all the other bars. Food is always fresh so no complaints at all!
author: JET T.

description:
Our pickup order was 30 minutes late, when we finally got to the food it wasn't prepared properly (e.g. the sunomono salad wasn't dressed with any vinegar). When I stopped by to complain the hostess just made excuses about the sushi chefs being busy and only eventually took any responsibility for the mistakes when I responded to her trite request "well, what do you want me to do about it?" with "an apology would be nice."

On top of all that, when I pointed out that I had given then a 20% tip for a pickup order the hostess lied to say that the restaurant didn't actually receive tips through GrubHub. What a trip. Needless to say, we won't ever be back. I now understand why Barracuda sushi, which used to be a favorite, went out of business since it was owned and operated by the same folks. I can only assume with service like we received today that Osaka sushi is close behind.
author: Jacob W.

description: Great happy hour 7 days a week from 4-6 many items in the menu. Food was good. Baked rolls are amazing! Location Is great. Service was good. Gets busy. Would return.
author: Ibelig V.

description: Every time I go there 30-15mins bfore close.. they r apparently already closed. I don't understand why u have closing hours when u just make up ur own anyway???? So they actually close 30 mins before their actual closing time.. it's not like it's a bar and the kitchen closes n the bar stays open.. it's a sushi place for goodness sake. Bla!! Last time I wasted my minutes walking up to this unfriendly joint.
author: Samira N.

description: I had the Dinner Bento Box with california rolls and chicken teriyaki. It was ok.
author: Arnaud H.

description:
I can't really find anything too special with this place. It was packed and service is ok... The waiter wasn't really happy when we wanted to change table and he wasn't too fond of my friend's request of replacing salmon sashimi with tuna in the bento box either.

Food was really mediocre. The caterpillar roll has a very mushy avocado. I ordered the unagi with rice and the unagi is kinda mushy as well. The price for bento box is really expensive. The same bento box costs a lot less in other sushi joints. Tempura has a nice batter, no complaints. 

I love seaweed salad, so I'm happy that my unagi comes with it.
author: Novalina N.

description:
I've never eaten anything here that stood out...in either way.   The food is fine, the sushi is good.   The prices however are up there...I usually stick with the meals here (bento box or similar) and it can cost upwards of $18!  

Would I recommend this place, sure...but there are better places out there for about the same price.   This place has a wonderful location which I am sure is the key to their success.
author: Matt V.

description: This review is mostly a review of their ramen which they advertise extensively with a sandwich board on the street and multiple postings around the restaurant.  One would think that ramen would be one thing of which this restaurant would be proud.  I will give this place two stars as their sushi is perfectly acceptable for a neighborhood establishment (nothing special...but fine).  The ramen was just awful.  now I know that there are as many styles of ramen as their are restaurants that serve it.  This was just very unimpressive.  No richness, No porky goodness.  No anything that would recommend it.  The miso ramen was essentially your run of the mill sushi restaurant miso soup with ramen noodles.  The serving of pork chashu was miniscule.  There were unnecessary pieces of fake crab or fish cake.  Not good at all.  My dining partner had the Shou ramen which while slightly better tasting (broth) was still rather unappealing.  If looking for ramen in The Castro I would recommend Wasabi Bistro where the ramen is at least acceptable.  I guess if you want great ramen in SF you gotta leave the Castro. Yamadaya in Japan Town is delicious.
author: Aaron C.

description: Had Spicy Tuna Hand-rolls, Power of Love, Red Dragon, and Unagi.  Really good, fresh and friendly good service. Charles was a great server!!
author: Randy W.

description:
Came during the block party to grab a drink and some food. What a great surprise.
The staff are super friendly (and calm given the chaos inside and out). Our drinks came out quickly, and the food followed soon after. The Volcano Roll was a particular favorite! Will definitely stop in next time I'm in town.
author: Ryan M.

description: Their Chirashi is creative and wonderful.  And so is the spicy dipping sauce that goes with it.  Max was a superb waiter and explained things very eloquently.   I can't wait to go back.  My only gripe is the décor is tired and drab.   On the other hand, if they glave the place a makeover, you would probably have to stand in line for hours.
author: Michael W.

description: Really good sushi but the service was very much lacking. It took almost 45 minutes to get our rolls which were delicious but I thought it was odd it took that long. I will say I will go back the food was really yummy. If you don't care about waiting and you want good food definitely give Osaka a try! I love the SF Giants roll delicious and definitely try the spicy tuna!
author: Nadia N.

description:
I love this place!!! 
The moment you walk in,  service is super great!! All the employees were attentive.  I ordered sashimi special, they are really fresh, sushi chef had magical touch each pieces,  which gave great flavor! Chicken karage was crispy and flavorful.  
I am sooooo coming back again!!
author: e j.

description: Ordered a to go bento box from here which turned out not only to be double the price of everywhere else, it was that mediocre I threw most of it away.
author: Drew B.

description: This rating is based solely on their decision to get rid of their lunch menu on weekends. I've been coming here for 10 years, but I'm not about to pay $19-22 for a bento box that I can get starting at $11 a few blocks away. Hope they reverse this change.
author: Derek I.

description: I had dinner here last night.  I ordered the ramen.  The noodles were good but not exceptional and the katsu in the soup was just okay.  I also ordered a regular spicy tuna roll which was fine.  The restaurant tables are too close together and it feels cramped.  Although the wait staff was nice, they were far from making me feel like my business mattered.  The menu does have a lot of choices so it may make for too many menu items done to "just okay" as there won't be a focus on perfecting each item.  If I am hungry for Japanese and I am on that block in the Castro, I may go back, but i can't see myself planning an advanced evening out for a nice dinner.
author: James W.

description: Dined with my boyfriend. Ordered seafood ramen with 3 rolls. Rolls were good. Ramen took a while to come to the table. That was fine, but my boyfriend had to go to work so we asked for the ramen to go. When we got to work we discovered it was NOT seafood but pork. (We are pescaterians) decided to take it back in hope of an exchange. When I had my boyfriend go back the waitress was upset that I did not tip and for having given us a merchant discount which the manger had informed us about. She also said "you need to learn to leave tip" Reasons for not tipping being: long wait, inattentive service and overall rude rude RUDE. All in all worst experience there, I feel so  disrespected . I work a block away in a food service establishment and I would NEVER demand a tip or complain about not receiving one to the customer. Although sushi was good I will not be returning and will make sure to let others know about this horrific experience.
author: E P.

description: Good luck getting any service. Thirty minutes seated in tables across the sushi bar during a half-empty Happy Hour and STILL no one went by my table. Don't bother with this place.
author: Hannah Y.

description: They have a gangsta roll, need more be said? Also friendliest sushi servers and they have GLUTEN FREE SOY SAUCE - happy day! The sushi was divine and the atmosphere was very fun and enjoyable .
author: Tatiana S.

description:
Ok, Osaka used to be our fav go-to place for sushi. Then, the service took a steep turn for the worst. We sat at a table for dinner, and the server(s) helped every other table around us except for ours. We eventually got helped and (much later) got our food, but we left feeling slighted. 

Fast forward a few months. We thought we'd give it another shot. This time we sat at the bar, knowing that in the past, one server handles the bar, and one or two handle the tables. And yet again, no hello, no menu, no service. We gave them 10 minutes to change our minds, and when no one came over, we got up and left. 

Sorry Osaka. We tried, but you failed.
author: Jenna H.

description: My parner and I have loved Osaka for years, and it has always been our go to place when in the City.  We visited today, and I don't know if there has been a change in ownership or what...but it was horrible.  We were so dissapointed in the food and service.  The miso soup was a different recipe, and did NOT taste good.  Sesame chicken had been removed from the menu, and our server didn't even know what it was..  the tempura...which used to be light and fluffy, with a light crispy crunch is now hard and dense.  Tooth breakers.  Dont know what has happrned, but the change isn't good.  We will not return.
author: Keith M.

description: Waited 30 minutes to eat, and then they rushed us out. Cleared dishes before we were even finished. The rolls were average, not great.
author: Jeffrey P.

description: Good rolls, and very reasonable prices :) I recommend
author: Jakub P.

description:
Food: The food here is alright, absolutely nothing special. I would expect better especially coming from the renowned Castro. The food is fairly priced but the food itself is just not appealing. The food there is just really.. well food. Don't have high expectations for this place. Just think of it as a cheap eats. Nothing special to drool over. 

As for the service, most of the servers there are excellent. Very nice and very attentive.
author: Brian T.

description: I needed to grab dinner before a double feature at the Castro Theatre & only had 25 minutes. The music they were playing was great, the service was friendly & efficient, the food delicious & I made it back across the street in time for the trailers.
author: Eli P.

description: Not the fanciest establishment by any stretch but they deserve the 5 stars. The rolls were huge, with generous portions of fish and very tasty. Very moderately priced, especially if you come around the happy hour. A perfect place to have a quick lunch in Castro.
author: Ilya K.

description:
Wow! I'm impressed. 4.5 stars 

Walk in and am kindly greeted by the chef's. We take our seats and are immediately waited upon. The server brought us water right away and gave us our menus. We pretty much had an idea of what to get so we ordered Miso soup and gyoza. Literally less than 5 minutes she came back with the items. I was very impressed at this point. Then when she brings the appetizers we order the Power of Love, Giants Roll, and Crazy Spicy roll. As we finish our miso soup out comes our order. Seriously guys? At a moderately packed place on a friday night it's this fast?! That's AMAZING! I was astonished at the speed of the rolls and how it tasted! I definitely will be back!

The only reason it's not a 5 is because the server was very moody and didn't seem to care :/ Cheer up buttercup!
author: Ezequiel R.

description: Nice variety of Japanese food offered. Authentic tasting (I am of Japanese descent so I can say this) quick service and reasonably priced. Definitely going back.
author: Marci N.

description: I thought it was awesome. Very nice sushi and spicy chirashi. Service was great, no wait, Professional discipline abounds. I did not get sick lol, and the lights were pretty! Recommendo.
author: Miguel L.

description:
I still have no idea why my friend and I decided to eat here when Barracuda is in close proximity, but we made the mistake and now I have no other option but to write a review describing my horrific experience.
I ordered the "gangsta" roll which is my favorite roll at Barracuda, but at Osaka it's quite another story. Not only was the rice hard and the fish not fresh BUT they also lacked the amazing cocktails Barracuda offers PLUS they were out of cabernet and I was forced to drink a disgusting glass of very cheap merlot which by the way I could not finish. As if this wasn't enough to make me want to cry, but the service was also poor and slow. 
I wll not be back! Ever!
author: Natalie M.

description:
I consider myself a regular during lunch hour and I'm always satisfied. I enjoy coming to Osaka for their seafood salad. The salad has fresh sashimi diced over greens with their delicious citrus dressing. It's always served with a fresh generous amount fish and just the perfect amount of dressing. However, I always feel like the plate tastes better when you order at the restaurant, rather than, take out.

I also enjoy eating their spicy tuna roll. It's always fresh, yet somewhat dry.

Their service can be slow at times, but I'm not sure if it's lack of servers or because I come during their busy part of the day.
author: Diana L.

description:
I can't get enough of this place. Its ironic; even after I think I've had my fill of their sushi rolls, I want it even more the next day. Will my sushi cravings ever go away? I'm insatiable, but Osaka on Castro is one of the few places that has come close to taming the wild sushi beast within me.

My most favorite things on their extensive sushi menu are: dragon roll (shrimp tempura & cucumber on the inside/unagi & avocado on the outside) & spicy crispy roll (unlike any sushi I've ever had-the whole thing, salmon/avocado/onion, is deep fried & topped with a spicy sauce.) I don't feel so guilty having all that fried goodness because it's so good, it's worth the extra mile on the treadmill.

My friend swears by their gangsta roll (i think he just likes to laugh at the name!), red dragon roll & pink lady roll. We usually get two rolls each & always have leftovers to take home.

Awesome vibe, very friendly waiters/waitresses, prices are reasonable, quick service. I will definitely be returning.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Sushi - 4 stars
Happy Hour Specials - 5 stars
Customer Service -  5 stars

So I guess this place really gets 4.5 :)  Awesome for being open all day too, unlike most places that close mid-day or don't open til 5.  Sometimes you just need sushi for happy hour!  Even non-happy hour prices were pretty reasonable.
author: Jen D.

description: 2.5 stars. Eh pretty average. Wouldn't come back. Ordered the sashimi and some of the fish was tough and not too fresh. Also the slices were pretty Tiny and expensive. I would go somewhere else.
author: Milla K.

description:
My review is based on experience solely with rolls. I usually get takeout from here or stop in if I need a quick bite. I've never considered getting Nigiri because the fish in my rolls is just okay, and it's very pricey for the size/quality - so the sushi has never been appealing. 

3 stars is justified by the fact that: 

1. The menu is overpriced 
2. Staff are pleasant enough, but not friendly, and I often wait quite awhile before someone comes to take an order or check-in. 
3. Totally mediocre quality, but the tempura rolls are tasty. 

There's better sushi in the Castro - go to Takara on 18th and Collingwood, about a block and half away. Much, much better, and cheaper. 

They do have a pretty cheap happy-hour which, if you're intent on trying it out, might be a more appropriate price-to-quality ratio.
author: Haley B.

description:
We were in the Castro and decided to give Osaka a try - some of our friends are regulars there, so we figured there must be something good going on. 

We ordered two of the special rolls.  They arrived lightning fast (I wondered how you could make them that fast).  When I took the first bite, I realized that the roll was hastily assembled - it didn't hold together well.  And something in the roll tasted a bit off.  The rest of the roll was inconsistent - some parts had more sauce, others none.  

But the worst was yet to come.  A short time after we finished dinner (it didn't taste so bad, so we finished it), I started having the runs.  Then some more.   Not to get into too many details, I'm now at home feeling pretty sick, and yes, I'm pretty sure the fish was to blame. 

Oh, and to top it off, my boyfriend is very sensitive to MSG, but it is a bit of a delayed reaction.  We're not sure which sauce it was in, but he's not feeling well, either. 

This place has gone on to my "never again" list of restaurants.
author: Dean A.

description: Good prices, service and portions, great sushi, I think i have been to this place every time I visit the city. They get quite creative with their rolls!
author: Carlos L.

description:
Pretty good sushi with good portions and was fresh. Tobiko was salty and was crunchy like popping candy-- my likes! Rolls were done properly that rice was firm and sticky. Uni was good but not the best quality. Amaebi was also quite good as it's not soggy.

Service was good and courteous. 

If I were to live in this neighborhood, it would have been my frequent spot!
author: T L.

description:
Perfect late night dinner. I guess the location makes everything for them, but the food and prices are very decent. 
My favorites by far are the power of love roll and tropical Napoleon dish. (yeah funky names, we are in the castro..)
Service is ok. I mean its a sushi place open almost all the time, service doesn't need to be perfect. 
Overall, its a good choice for a small bite when passing by the castro.
author: Alice G.

description:
When sushi is done wrong, it's heartbreaking and infuriating. I've never come to Osaka and had a satisfying meal, either the fish was not fresh and flavorful or they missed the mark in some other way. 

I was not feeling the love. 

There are too many other sushi places to go to that are really decent in the area. 
Try Sushi Time, and Eiji's. You wont be disappointed.
author: Tasha A.

description:
For $8.95 you can have one of their lunchboxes. And if you were thinking, like my lunch companion did today, that said lunchbox will leave you less than satiated, think again!

The lunchbox comes with a variety of choices including salmon teriyaki, tonkatsu, California roll, tempura, etc. Of these, you can have two. Along with your two selections, you also get miso soup, salad, a small serving of edamame, an orange slice and a scoop of rice. And don't forget, hot tea!

Bottom line is this, Osaka rocks. And for so little cash!
author: Miriam W.

description:
Even with the fairly poor review that I've given in the past, I continue to go back all the time because it's one of the very few places in the Castro for sushi. Although it hasn't become amazingly great, it has improved a bit over time (which is always a good thing).

My friend Will and I visit Osaka often, and generally have a tasty and filling meal (before or after a fun night of drinks). 

One of the greatest improvements that Osaka has made was the hiring of Michelle as a server. Generally, the servers here are both inattentive and rude. Michelle, on the other hand, is always incredibly friendly and an outgoing person. The first time I went in to have lunch and read my book, it was a slow day and she stopped to chat with me about what I was reading, as well as what she was reading at the time. And when I left, she was extremely sweet and caring. 

I thought it was a one time deal, but coming back with a friend for dinner later on, she was the exact same bubbly and friendly person. While dinner was quite tasty, she made it an even better time.

Come in for the specialty rolls (they have a flaming roll that they serve to your table on fire, and that's pretty neat), enjoy the wonderful scenic options of the Castro (if you're lucky enough to get a table by the window), and cross your fingers that you'll be lucky enough to have Michelle be your server.
author: Nicolas H.

description: Oh, to be in Castro, to be tipsy, to have access to raw fish, I love it! I'll have to revisit this review when I patron this place sober. Until then, it gets three-and-a-half stars, with a little nudge up to four just cuz it's on Castro. The sushi is amazing...when I'm drunkish. The prices are a little higher than my norm, but it's priced for Castro so that's expected. I wish I can give you better details on the quality of their food, but again, I come here drunkish and everything tastes good in that state.
author: Helen L.

description:
It won't win any awards for best sushi in the city but it has great hours, super friendly staff and a wide selection of sushi. 

If the prices were just a tad lower, I'd feel perfectly fine giving Osaka Sushi a 4 star rating. But for what you get, they might be a tad over priced. But what else would you expect in San Francisco, on Castro Street just a block from Market!
author: Justin S.

description:
Came here for a quick snack after a debacle at another place... long story....

It was happy hour, so I got several items, all were pretty good, but it just wasn't the BEST sushi I have had, it was ok.

I had two 2-piece salmon (although I asked for one 2-piece, she ordered me two)  It was nice and fresh salmon, big pieces.

I also had the crunchy shrimp rolls from the happy hour.  It was ok.  To me a crunchy shrimp roll has avocado and/or Krab meat, this just had the shrimp, rice, seaweed, and i think celery? some green that I cannot remember at this moment.  It was good, but I guess you get what you pay for... not amazing.  It was wrapped normal (seaweed on outside) as opposed to inside out that I normally like on crunchy shrimp rolls.

I got the post stickers, these were probably the highlight of the meal.  Pretty tasty, well cooked, and a nice dippy sauce.  If I go back, I would definitely get these.   

I finished with the tempura.  Came with one shrimp and assorted veggies.  The tempura was totally coated, kinda heavy, almost coated if you can imagine like an onion ring.  Not that light a delicate tempura coating you are used to. The tempura dippy sauce was not that pungent that I am use to.  And I think with the heavyness of the tempura batter, they came out overly greasy. 

I dinned by myself, and for about $30 with happy hour pricing, I felt it was a little pricey.  I had a beer (which I think was $2.50) so I cannot report on their soda ability (canned or fountain)

I may go back, it is in a convenient location in the Castro.. I'll give them a second try with my husband...
author: David P.

description: Got the 3 item Bento lunch box. Ended up being $15 so I expected some good quality food. The Veggie tempura was tastless, the spicy tuna roll was not fresh at all - tuna tasted mushy and the rice was hard and bland. Miso soup was okay. Won't be wasting my money here again.
author: Macaulay H.

description:
I was thinking to myself whether or not to rate this place 3 STARS or 3.5 STARS. As I continued to eat my meal, I decided to give it 3 STARS. The service is good. The decor is your typical Japanese everyday sort of thing. The food ranges from good to okay to "meh, not coming here again but still edible".

I'm very picky when it comes to Japanese restaurants because I have eaten at a bunch of them, and love really good Japanese food. With that said, this place is decent but nothing to come back for or rave about.

Me and my girlfriend ordered their Bento Lunch Box, Caterpillar Roll, and Grilled Oysters. For our Bento Lunch Box we decided on Spicy Tuna Roll + Chicken Karaage, and Ebi Tempura Roll + Chicken Teriyaki. 

The Spicy Tuna Roll was "MEH, I've had a lot better...not coming back here for that." Their Chicken Karaage was pretty good, because it had a nice crunch to it but was not soaked in oil. Although I've had better, it was good. Their Ebi Tempura Roll was "umm...no." As for their Chicken Teriyaki, when compared to Tani's Kitchen...it makes this place look like a chump. The flavor is lacking and the teriyaki sauce is more on the watery side.

Their Catepillar Roll was the best out of all the dishes we ordered. I would say this is a 4 STAR  sushi roll. The rice tasted fresh and had a good flavor. The sushi was tight and compact. And the portions of avocado, eel, and cucumber were on point. 

Finally, their Mussels were a let down. The flavor and ingredients they used was REALLY GOOD! It had like this sweet and spicy sauce with the fish eggs. Although it tasted good, they over cooked it to the point of it being REALLY TOUGH and CHEWY :(.

I realize this might be the only Japanese place in the castro, but when compared to other places in SF and even in San Mateo, this place is a 3 STARS at best.
author: Nick C.

description:
I dine here at least once a week and always been satisfied with the food and the service. (I shouldn't be reviewing a restaurant late at night since I get hungry thinking of yummy food). My favorite in the menu is the chirashi - a bowl of rice topped with a variety of sashimi slices and pickled daikon and plum. The portion can be too much (now that's a good thing) that I have the rest of the food bentoed to go. 

You know when you eat in a sushi restaurant the portions can be so tiny you end up ordering more food and spending at least fifty of your hard earned money? Well, depending on what day it is and who the sushi chef is, the portions seem to be on the generous side. Expect to spend $20-25 per person for dinner without drinks and your tummy will say: "Arigato gozaimasu".
author: Errol F.

description:
Looking for another snack in Castro and came in here.  On a Sunday afternoon around 2-3pm, we had a choice of tables.  We took one of the booth seats and settled down.  

There are colored papers listing specials on the wall.  Ambiance lighting - on the darker side.

What we had: 
large sapporo $6 
fresh oysters - 4 pc - $6.95, green onion. tobiko and ponzu sauce??  not cold enough, which really ruins the oysters
 
lobster salad roll - $8.95 - can't taste lobster, too much mayo, the cucumber was not very thin with too much sriracha sauce but it's not a good brand so it was just too sweet with no heat

crazy spicy roll - spicy tuna, hamachi & salmon with spicy masago - 5 pieces - ok but not spicy - $7.95
author: Gloria H.

description:
After walking around the Castro to check out all the 4 star sushi spots, only to find them closed on a Monday night we decided to enter Osaka Sushi. A little too touristy for my taste, but for a Monday being packed it must be decent. I skewed away from my traditional order and asked them what they were famous for. I was recommended the Sweet Heart roll, Castro roll and the Crazy roll and threw in a little chicken karage just for a little craziness.

Rolls were not bad. Out of the three the Crazy roll was da bomb... The other two were a little too foo foo for me, to much sweet on the Sweet Heart and the Castro was practically the same. As for the karage - Meh...

But after swinging by the Barracuda Sushi joint and sitting there 15 mins w/ no service... This place is da bomb... in the Castro...
author: Minh V.

description: This used to be our go to place in the neighborhood but it has steadily declined in quality. Their food is OK but the sushi has become questionable. We just had 5 roles of which 3 were bland and a bit fishy; the CA roll rated like canned crab. The Otokoyama roll is still good. I'll come here for a lunch box but I think my dinner visits are done for good now.
author: Richard J.

description:
I noticed a friend of mine on facebook checked in here a lot so I happened to be in the castro so I gave it a shot 
I ordered the bento box with spicy tuna , California roll and salad and miso soup - delicious I will definitely come back you can't beat the price $11.40 with tax fresh and tasty !!
author: lyn m.

description: Nice, clean little place. Service was just a little slow, otherwise they would have gotten 5 stars. All 4 of us enjoyed our dinners.
author: Jacque Y.

description:
Happy Hour, that's all I can say. Sapporo beers. Large. Happy hour. Yes.

So my friends treated me to some sushi. I am a sushi skeptic outside of my Vancouver sushi bubble where I can get the best in North America, but it was actually alright. The big pieces of raw fish were particularly awesome and they didn't taste fishy (hey, come on!)

Their spicy tuna roll was probably one of the spiciest rolls I've had, and that's a good sign.
author: Gina I.

description: Great location and great happy hour.   The service is ok for a small place.  I highly recommend going in on an off time or early for a nice meal right on Castro Street.
author: Chad J.

description:
Came here for lunch last week with my Best Friend as a last minute lunch before she headed to work down the street. It was my first time eating here and can I say what a disappointment. I used to always pass by this place on my way to Geary where my alumni is located and I would always wonder how good it must be being in the castro and all.

Well about the food:
Ordered their lunch special, 3 items for $12+ which is actually a bit pricey for me, especially for 1/2 grade food.  It came with miso soup which tasted like dish water and a salad which wasn't too bad, but how can you go wrong with salad? The box came with a Fried Ebi Roll, Salmon Teriyaki and Sashimi. Sashimi was fresh & came with 3 pieces of Salmon and 2 pieces of Tuna. That was probably the only good part of the box. The Salmon Teriyaki was bland and for some reason the teriyaki sauce they used had the consistency of jelly???? Weird I know. And the Fried Ebi Roll [pretty much a shrimp tempura roll] was DISGUSTINGLY DRY! So dry that with one bite the seaweed, and rice stuck to the palette of my mouth. 

NEVER GOING BACK HERE. For being in the castro I would've expected better food. On top of that the waitresses were somewhat rushy, pushy and didn't let us take our time while ordering. 

TRY YOUR LUCK. YOU MIGHT LIKE IT THOUGH.
author: Dessa S.

description:
I love Osaka sushi. I think their food is great, and it's convenient for me.
 I recently discovered their happy hour and have become a regular, visiting once or thrice a week for hot sake and spicy oysters. 
But the last few weekends I have been in with friends, it hasn't been as enjoyable. 
Today I got total attitude from the waiter with Pink hair. 
I just finished work, was tired and very sore from being beaten up on muni a few days earlier, and just wanted some hot sake to relax and soothe me. I ordered from the nice waiter I hadn't seen before, and waited for my friend to meet me. Just as he arrived the other waitperson showed up and asked what he could get us. I said I just wanted sake, he said you have to order food we don't just serve drinks. So when our waiter came back my friend ordered a $14 roll.  He went to the restroom and on returning he overheard the other waiter telling our waiter to make sure we order food. 
 Ok is that some kind of law?? 
I've brought too many friends in there to be treated like that.  The weekday server knows my order and asks if I'm having the same as soon as I arrive. That's the kind of service that brings me back. 
 Guess I'll just avoid weekends and pink hair.
author: Todd S.

description: Service was awful AND it's a slow day at 3:30pm. Our server forgot to bring our tea, and our sake. Then 20 minutes later I ask him and he says it's no longer stocked.
author: Monk R.

description: I liked everything I ordered, from the bento box with chef's choice sashimi, to the dragon roll. The nigiri is on the pricey side, so be mindful when ordering.
author: Frank L.

description: I was here a few years ago and have been thinking about the great food ever since. I had lunch here today and the food was still great but there was a big difference between service staff, one was pretty rude while others were great. I'd still come back for the food but maybe at a different time to avoid rude staff members.
author: P M.

description:
I had totally forgotten about this place until a friend recently treated me to lunch there. I'm grateful for the reminder! Not only is the sushi tasty, fresh and made with love, but they also have a giant selection of veggie options. Plus, if you get the veggie combo, you can choose several types, experimenting with new flavors while always keeping the avocado mainstay on your plate.

If only we lived in a world where miso soup could be made without fermented fish guts (aka fish sauce).
author: Stumbalina b.

description:
Its alright...

The fish is just ok, and the other dishes are agreeable. Customer service tends to vary a lot. If its late, and you got a craving, perhaps give it a try. Otherwise move onto to All Season or Barracuda.
author: Daren D.

description: I ordered takeout from this joint once.  It's not bad and will do the trick.  However, the tempura and the beef terriyaki were just not up to the caliber that i am traditionally used to.  Specifically, the tempura was a little bit soggy.  The chicken was okay, but the sauce was a bit too watery.  Everything else was just a cut below what I am used to.  Now, I am probably a bit of a Japanese food snob (and I don't mean to be), but I'd come back again.
author: Johnny Y.

description: OK sushi. Actually this place has fresher fish than some of the other joints who claim to be sushi bar so I'll bump it up to 4 stars. Service is quick and attentive and the sashimi is pretty good. I usually get the chirashi sushi and am never disappointed here.
author: Kenson K.

description:
I was in here once before and thought the food was sub par especially for the 'regular prices'... I thought you would get what you pay for had it been about 30%-40% less expensive. Needless to say I was disappointed. So a couple
Days ago I planned on going to my regular sushi spot, Takara, 'cept they're closed on Tuesday's, and I thought what the hell, I'll go to Osaka. I got the lady in pink roll and the cali roll with real crab. The crab meat was dry and tasted old, and was much less than satisfactory. The pink lady roll on the other hand wasn't bad. It was kind of good actually, though I've had much better. 2 mediocre visits in a row and I'm convinced I won't eat here again, but who knows, I may have another time where this could be my substitute, but with 3 other great sushi restaurants within walking distance, don't count on it. 

I've read quite a bit of reviews about bad service here, but I have yet to encounter such a inconvenience...  

Verdict- great place but the food isnt!!!
author: Justin O.

description:
4 oysters for $6.95! They are pretty good too! The size ranges from tiny to med-size. Other than that everything was borderline okay. 

My gf ordered a sashimi lunch and it was too tiny for its price! I think it was around $17 and it only had 3 tiny pieces of salmon, 2 tiny tuna, and maybe 2 or 3 other tiny weak slices. We were like... what?? You call this lunch?

I wasn't satisfied with my orders too. The spicy scallop was blargh. They did not even cut the scallop into tiny pieces. It looks like they just smeared it with sriracha sauce and stuffed it into a hand-roll. 

My white tuna nigiri was so-so. 
I like my sushi pretty traditional and fresh so I don't think i will be coming back here..
author: Miss C.

description:
Went in last night before working next door at Q Bar. Was worried about time because I had only 30 minutes to order, eat, and pay. The sushi came almost right away and it was fresh, tasty goodness. The albacore sashimi here is bomb! FAT fatty tuna, just the way I like it. I would suggest that they make a special dipping sauce for the O-Toro.. not sure what the name is but I've had that pairing at most other Japanese restaurants.

I love the large glasses of ice water they give you! the sushi chef was very friendly and fast and I was in and out of there with 5 minutes to spare. Thanks Osaka!
author: Natalie N.

description: I don't plan on eating here again. I got the chicken teriyaki bento box with tempura and a salmon/avocado roll on the side. The chicken teriyaki was DRY. it was like leather. I could have made better. I've never had a teriyaki that wasn't moist and delicious until this place. The tempura was also not great. I can't quite explain what was wrong with it, it just felt off. Normally I devour tempura but found myself struggling to finish this stuff. Also the fish I had was mushy. When I put a piece of the roll in my mouth, I couldn't distinguish the salmon from the avocado in terms of texture. It was not very good and wasn't cheap either. My friend who suggested the place said he'd been there before and that it had been better. So maybe that was just an off night.
author: Kyle J.

description:
This is one of my favorite sushi places in the city. They have yet to let me down in taste and variety. In Japan there aren't a lot of specialty rolls, only nigiri and sashimi. I enjoy more bursts of flavors. I do love nigiri and sashimi but sometimes your taste buds needs a kick of flavor. 

I especially love this place because of its late hours. When it gets full however this place really feels cramped. If you need to go to the restroom, before you get there, there's a sigh that tells you to wait in the hall. The door is usually closed, so sometimes you can't tell if it is occupied or not and you stand there all foolishly for awhile.

I have been to many sushi places in SF and this is still my personal favorite. It by far has the most variety on its menu. And it's located in the Castro, always a fun place to visit, there's always some drama or interestingly drunk people around! I love it!
author: C L.

description:
There probably as many sushi places in San Francisco as there are fish in the sea.  I haven't yet met a piece of sushi I didn't like, but finding originality in a commodity like fish in a place like SF can sometimes be challenging.  Case in point: on the whole, Osaka is a really cute little place, but fairly unremarkable.  And yet, there are a couple special touches that bring it up from a, "Hm.  Well, I'm glad I tried that." to a "Like muchly, would eat again."

Osaka, in true San Franciscan restaurant style, is a small, rectangular space.  Running along one side is the sushi bar, and along the other are several tables, chairs, and bench seats run along the wall.  The atmosphere is very casual, and I remember being seated across from the requisite marker board telling me the day's specials in neat handwriting.

I was lucky enough to be there with some friends at happy hour, where the deals were really quite good and where we were presesnted with a small menu of appetizer-like tasties, each for around $5 or less.  The regular prices were quite a bit more expensive, but the special rolls are large, and the quality is very good.

There were two dishes that really bumped Osaka up to a place of legitness in my mind.  The first was the Chirashi.  It's expensive, but if you're not super hungry it's actually enough for two.  It was this dish that introduced me to the glory of butterfish.  I don't know if it's all butterfish, or just the stuff they serve at Osaka but Oh.  Mygod.  I have never met an edible that was more aptly named.  All the other fishies were fresh and clean and served over rice that was gloriously sticky and sweet.  The other dish that I would really recommend is the Spicy Crispy Roll.  As someone who tries to be health-conscious, I don't really do the fried roll thing very often.  So I was a little dismayed to see so many "crispy" offerings.  However, the salmon was fried so perfectly, and that plus the avocado and tobiko (different colors for each piece!) made for a truly extravagant treat.

In a city veritably swimming with tasty raw fish bits, I don't know if I'd go out of my way to go to Osaka.  But you can bet that if I find myself in the Castro again, it's going to be hard to keep me away.
author: Becca S.

description: Ok food. I'm holding out returning until their city health score improves. 61 out of 100 is not very good.
author: Jim C.

description: The atmosphere was weird... They were playing pop and country songs... Need I say more? Okay I will. I ordered an asparagus roll and a avocado roll- they were okay, but def not the best. 10 minutes after leaving the restaurant I got sick and threw up. That's just no bueno. I won't be visiting there again.
author: Shane R.

description:
Probably my favorite sushi restaurant in the city - its not too pricey (for the quality that you get) and the people there are really friendly.  Its not that big, holds ~30 people.... and give that great "small-atmosphere" feel to it
the rolls that are on the white board, are the besdt, you gotta try at least one.........
author: Ken T.

description:
The spicy crunch roll is not what one would expect for the name.. oh no.  First of all, the CRISPY one is fried... the crunchy one is rolled in eggs.  Just to clear that up.

It was the perfect sushi... the rice was well cooked and flavored, the nori was not too mushy or tough; and the insides were amazingly fresh and well flavored.  The crunch roll is filled with a spicy tuna mix and was wonderful, very spicy.  The kappa make was adorable in presentation with uneven pieces sticking about- quite wonderful... totaled to $13.

The tempora udon was my favorite- everything about that udon was perfection in a steaming bowl of broth, tempura and thick wheat noodles.  The vegetables were fresh and it was a gianormous bowl for only $13.. which in retrospect seems expensive, but for quality sake was great.

Finally, my recommendation to all of you.. try the unfiltered Nigori sake for $4.50 a glass.  It is cloudy in appearance, smooth and has almost a coconut milk taste and texture- amazing flavor and not the typical nail polish sake.

Seating is not as fun, and more window seating would appeal for another star.
author: Sasha S.

description: The fish is fresh enough but not mind blowing and the rolls are just ok.  Presentation trumps taste here in my opinion.  After eating here twice I decided that with all of the sushi joints in the city that I haven't tried...I probably wouldn't go here again.  It was good but not great.  I will say that my server both times was very nice
author: Liz B.

description:
HAPPY HOUR 3PM-6:30PM

Love the oysters, tuna rolls and gyoza.

If your saving money for dinner and want JAPANESE food come here!
author: Aemar E.

description:
I went here on my last night while visiting my friends in San Fransisco. It was one of the better sushi places I've been to in sf. I thought it was a little pricey at first, but once the sushi came. I changed my mind. It tasted fresh and the rolls where larger than I was used to! I remember I could barely finish my three rolls I ordered. I know, I'm a fat kid.

The wait staff could be a little friendlier.
author: Jason L.

description: This sushi bar, across from Castro Theatre, proved to be a perfect source of delicious food before the Alan Cumming show tonight.  Service was attentive and rapid, the atmosphere was friendly, comfortable, and we enjoyed some sake with the crazy roll and a tuna roll that was awesome.  Unfortunately I don't remember all the items we had but everyone was thrilled with the meal and some nice hot sake and miso soup to keep us warm.  I am definitely coming here again when I am in town, and you should check it out.
author: Ellen O.

description:
The food is average and pricey....with this being said the SERVICE is always friendly and helpful... there are better sushi but the friendly staff keeps me coming back to this one...

$15 for Udon Noodles...really?
author: Blake J.

description:
I ordered the chiefs choice, 7 sashimi, 7 nigri and a seaweed salad. The food came out very timely and the service was about average. The fish was fresh but not as good as I have had other places. It was also room temperature and I prefer my raw fish very cold... but that is personal preference I guess.

If you like gimmicky rolls that feature sauces, creamcheese, and cooked fish, then this place is probably great for you. The fresh raw fish was just ok.
author: Liz K.

description:
Hm.

I can only speak on this place oh so much, as I only come here for the Happy Hour specials (minus one dinner venture). The sushi here is OKAY. Nothing to write home about. I've definitely had better. The service here is HORRIBLE. ALL of the times I've been here, my/our waiter has either gotten an item wrong, mixed up or handed it to an adjoining table...the table of someone I don't know.

I would say if you do plan on checking this spot out, do it during happy hour so you don't feel like so much of an ass for paying full price for horrible service.
author: Trav M.

description:
Excellent variety of unique rolls. My faves are the "Power of Love" Roll and the "gangsta" roll. Sit at the counter to have a chat with the sushi chef and enjoy the daily specials. which are numerous and delicious! Don't forget the mochi for dessert.
Also, friendly and cute staff, but there will most likely be a wait for dinner.
author: Emily G.

description:
-1 star for not having sustainable sushi

-1 star for not friendly service

-1 star for mediocre rolls

+2 stars for being open late and having decent sushi
author: Wren X.

description: Just finished eating supper here and the food was amazing.  Kobe beef nigiri, spicy crunchy roll and inari; so well prepared.  The flavor balance and textures couldn't have been better.
author: Kameron H.

description: I'm vegan, so my perspective on sushi restaurants is a little different.  We ordered inari, a shittake roll, a ume roll and a noodle soup between two of us.  Each thing was good, but not amazing.  It's a cute little restaurant.  I wouldn't go out of my way to hit up this place, but I wouldn't avoid it either.
author: Douglas P.

description: traveled last week , had nice business lunch . would come again
author: Slava S.

description:
My BF has a special place in his heart for the Jive-Ass Roll.  It is because he is a round-eye white british bulldog.  He appreciates a good nigiri as well, but there are times when he goes weak in the knees for some roll layered with stuff and drowning in sauce.  Last night was one such night.

We had an hour to kill before seeing Inglorious Bastards at the Castro theater.  We had some dinner here.  2 rolls, 1 edamame, 1 sunomono and a large hot sake later, I was stuffed to the gills!  And it cost around $50 for the things listed above.  I was overstuffed but still malnourished.

Think about this: the rolls here average $12.  It's 6 sloppy, messy, drippy pieces.  That's 2 dollars a piece.  For nigiri, it's not cheap either.  Hamachi was $5.50.  I attribute the high prices to the tony location and attempts at being posh.  It's not a reflection on the quality.  Recently, I've had some of the best sushi of my life.  That's because I grew something called standards.  Sure, they're not the highest, but they're higher than yours.  

When I was young and naive, I was impressed by this place.  Now that my taste buds have evolved, this place is something i do to make the BF happy.  Like that thing in bed you do to make your mate happy but the whole time you're wishing you were doing something else.  

It's a fun place and the couple next to us were having the wildest conversation.  I just wish that the food was better.
author: Christina C.

description:
Three strikes you are OUT!

Came back again with my friend for happy hour sushi got there at 5:30PM well before happy hour ended...ordered three happy hour rolls and sake...so far so good - I so badly wanted you to redeem yourself from my last experience there.  5:50PM yeah, it's getting busy, wanted to order another round of sake but our server is nowhere to be seen...wait person finally gets to us - 6:04PM - I said "we'd like another round", and she quickly replies -"oh, sorry happy hour is over" (WTF!) on top of that one order never came!  You have got to be fucking kidding me!!!  Have some class! If a patron gets there well before happy hour you honor your damn happy hour prices - what a damn disappointment!!! And, unfortunately, that will be my last time there. I'll walk up the extra block to All Season Sushi for now on.
author: Tiberius A.

description:
I am unsure if my standards have lowered from having terrible Japanese food in the Phoenix-area for the past three months, but the food here was decent and fairly priced. I ordered a tempura udon, a spicy tuna roll, and a spider roll, all of which I was satisfied with.

I would have given them four stars, if it were not for our inattentive server; it was almost impossible to get her attention. 

Overall, it was a good meal!
author: L L.

description:
I went here last night with a few fresh out of college graduates to celebrate. It was the perfect place to go to for dinner. The place was pretty packed but service was fast, friendly, and attentive. Once seated, we opened our menus to begin the epic battle of which rolls to order.

You know it's a good sushi place when your mouth starts watering as you read about their specialty rolls. Fried rolls, spicy rolls, saucy rolls, me oh my. I really couldn't decide so we did a bit of the eeny meeny mony moe. I ordered: The castro, rainbow, and crunch and munch.

Second sign of a good sushi place: delicious miso. YUMMM. The sushi was done very quickly. Rolls were tight (just the way i like it, baby). Castro and Crunch & Munch rolls were really good. Fried, drizzled with whatever that magic terriaki sushi mayo sauce is, and topped with delicious fresh fish. The rainbow roll was also good but not the best I've ever had. I wish they used more variety of fish in the "rainbow" part of it.

The only downside was that their unagi had bones in it and dinner was a bit on the pricey side.
author: Michelle N.

description: I've been a loyal customer for several years.  This is a solid lunch and occasional dinner place. Today disappointed at during my work lunch break - after being seated and never received my menu or water after 10 minutes.  Eventually got up since no one came by. There were only 3 other tables all who were eating or finished eating. If you are in a rush be wary.
author: Brian Y.

description: I was surprised at the quality of sushi here. I foolishly assumed that because it was on Castro street it would be subpar, but no. I had the San Francisco Fire, seared tuna, some deepfried action, some spicy sauce. Delicious! I also had a basic avocado salmon roll. My partner said his beef terryiaki was average. I will definately be back for a late dinner before heading to the bar or club.
author: Mark S.

description: Just walked by Osaka and it is closed for continued health violations.  Yuck.
author: laurel t.

description: Good sushi, miso and tea - nice people (very friendly!) - pretty good atmosphere.
author: Jason B.

description: The pricing was good.  The location was convenient.  I didn't get anything too fancy but I can't remember what it was called.  It was tasty.  I was hungry.  It did the job.  I wouldn't go out of my way to this place though. I just come here when I'm screaming around the Castro.
author: Grace P.

description: Food and drinks cheap cheap. I was waiting for my Friends to go to the night club we never made it.  all of us we got so much  fun in osaka and we got drunk. we end up drinking and smoking over the streets on castro.. Police very friendly. we almost got arrrested for intoxication over area anyway  back to osaka the server are so cool and friendly as well. the restaurant is not the great but Me and friend are super cool we are really easy. we had great time in this place until they close
author: Cesar E.

description: Ah, I have gotten food poisoning here too many times now.  I used to come here a lot but not at all now.  Especially when I heard another friend tell me they have gotten food poisoning here too.  It's a shame.  Not sure what is going on there.
author: Dougg K.

description:
this might be the only sushi place in town that DOESN'T close between 2 and 5.  and thank god for that, because when a mean sushi craving hits between those hours and undergound sushi time, barracuda's and sushi delight have all closed their doors on you... Osaka is not a far stroll away.

AND... their sushi is good!  they had interesting veggie options (for me) and my boyfriend had a red dragon roll and said it was fresh and tasty.  so we are now big fans.  having said that, if you're looking for veggie options, i'd steer away from the japanese squash roll.  the texture was kinda nasty and it wasn't much for flavor.  we had an asparagus roll and a plum and cucumber roll as well, and those were good.

thanks for not shutting down sushi options when i'm in the mood!

lastly, i MUST mention their wasabi.  that's the strongest wasabi i've ever had!!!  it was amazing.  i did the usual dissolving of a big ol' chunk into my soy sauce... and the result was my eyes watering, sinuses clearing, and that weird moment where you think you might burst into flames and/or stop breathing.  it was amazing.  i dunno WHAT they do to kick it up higher than the usual wasabi, but i'm a fan!
author: Beccie F.

description: This place looks like a hole in the wall but actually has good sushi. I ate there twice and recommend the 49er (a house special). It's better to eat on a weekend, the sushi is fresher. Great service, put lemon on the salmon....yum!
author: Sora A.

description:
I've been going to this place for many years, mostly because of the "pros" listed below.

Pros: open rather late (until 11 on week-days I believe, midnight on week-end), very large selection of food, from sushi to cold udon. I am really happy they serve ika yaki.

Cons: Most rolls are of the fried/SweetSauce/unagi/mayo laden type - I am much into traditional sushi. Sushi quality itself is just OK. Staff is ok, but not specifically super friendly.
author: bart m.

description:
Pricing is normal for a sushi restaurant.
Love their Volcano Roll! 
It's tuna with spicy sauce and crunchy seaweed salad on top.
The sake they have is also yummy.
The selection is big, so sometimes I get a little bit annoyed when they come back so quickly to ask you what you want, which seems to be common in Asian restaurants, but I keep end up ordering Volcano Roll because it's so delicious.
Staff is friendly and attends to needs quickly.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Wow, this place was really wonderful.  Creative AND delicious rolls. And OMG, for the fried rolls they batter and fry EACH PIECE instead of battering/frying the whole roll and then cutting it up.  

I'm giving it 4-stars instead of 5 because I was really surprised at how expensive everything was.  5 people, 6 rolls, and 3 beers = $180?!?!?!  How does that work... 

I'll be back. yum yum yum.
author: Maryam S.

description: I consider myself a sushi connoisseur and this was by far some of the best sushi I have ever had in my life. super big, fluffy rolls filled with any goodness of your choosing. Highly Recommended.
author: A S.

description: Terrible! I heard so but i was so hungry for Sushi that i didnt pay attention to past reviews. Service was a nightmare. My order was never completed and while i was waiting for the rest of my food to arrive (about 15 minutes) they brought me the check instead....DONT GO THERE....
author: Gabriel G.

description: Average food but open late.  Prices are to high for what you get.  Almost $20 for an average bento box???
author: Daniel A.

description: I am a sushi lover, but wasn't very happy with the customer service. I asked about the specials, and was totally ignored. I didn't have sushi there but the Dinner Bento. It was served when I got my meso. The meso was good but boiling hot so hot I burnt my tougue. The same goes for the tea. There is something wrong about ordering food that is so hot that you have to let it cool before you consume it. It wasn't the best. The salad wasn't that great. Limp and watery dressing.  More likely I won't want to eat there again.
author: Alan O.

description:
Let me first disclose that though I have rated Osaka with 2 stars, I still go there constantly (3 times in the last 10 days).  

But I don't know why!!!!   Yes, the location is great.  Yes, at happy hour I can have Sapporo & a spicy tuna roll for $6.  

But, the sushi is far from the best in the vicinity, and more than anything,the service SUCKS!!!  Slow and uncaring.  As soon as I find another good sushi happy hour in spitting distance, I'm out of there...
author: Doug V.

description:
This place was ok.  

I dropped by with a gal-friend before attending Breakfast at Tiffany's at the Castro last week. 

We asked if we could come in and just have a bottle of Sake and they said no, you have to order some food. WTF?

Well, I was snaky and had about 45 minutes, so I ordered Agadashi (Tofu) and some Sashimi with a bottle of Nigori (unfiltered Sake). Everything was ok. Nothing outstanding but good. Service was attentive. I prefer the Agadashi at Nihon and the Sashimi at Mikado by far so... Those get 5 stars, and Osaka Gets 3. But let me make clear, outside of being denied service initially, everything was pleasant.
author: Adam X.

description:
Nomy nom nom!

I imagine I will be more inclined to try the other options the Castro has to offer but I can see this place being a standby. Much better than the Osaka on Fillmore.
author: Alexis B.

description:
Unique creamy rolls. I like their specialty rolls over the traditional rolls. 

Off the menu-
Hot Spot Roll- if you like scallops, you gotta try this roll. The spicy taste matches the spring onions with an undertone of scallops. 

On the menu-
Red Dragon Roll- eels and more eels! 

I like the presentation, cute sushi bar, good green tea. 
I wish it was a bit cheaper but for $20 you can get a decent lunch here. Sushi is quality.
author: Jack C.

description:
Take-out a couple times and eat-in a couple times.

Good table service. Fresh sushi. the castro roll was delicious. 

Will keep coming back.
author: hansel s.

description:
I can't speak to the sushi as I didn't get that here, but I the unagi kabayaki I had there was pretty good.  The sauce was appropriately sweet, although just a tad too sweet.  I think they did it to cover up the fact that the eel wasn't super fresh, although it was still quite good.  I thought it was a pretty average price, but I appreciated the quick food service.  The miso soup came out right away, and the entree followed not too long after, so you have something to munch on immediately.  I'm surprised that this place was so crowded, but I guess almost every restaurant on Castro St is packed on a Friday night.  We were cool with sitting at the sushi bar, so we got seated immediately, but waiting for a table or a booth would have taken awhile.

I'd probably go back if friends wanted to, but I wouldn't pick it myself.  It's ok.
author: William C.

description:
Walked in here on a Thursday night with my good college friend after a adventurous MUNI ride that left me starving. The place is cramped, and the bathroom is fairly comfortable, but only for one person at a time. -_-
When it came to the food, the rolls fit their prices. 
No disappointment when it came to the spicy mayo. 
We were disappointed when we ordered tempura ice cream for dessert and what we got was more tempura than green tea ice cream. 
I'm hoping to come back during happy hour.
author: Cerina C.

description: Very nice vegetable tempura and tofu teriyaki. Also, the yakiniku don was great. Excellent value for money plus good service
author: J R.

description:
On treatment:

I am currently reading 'Garlic and Sapphires' by Ruth Reichl in which due to her picture being in every restaurant in New York Reichl has to disguise herself in order to properly perform her job as the food critic at the New York Times. In the process she learns a lot about people. She dresses up as Molly, a dumpy overweight woman who only demands her right to good service and the wine menu on rare occasions. 

Well funny thing, you would have thought I was a Molly going into Osaka sushi months ago. My friend Darlene and I, obviously young hipsters, enter the restaurant and are apparently the only women there. This was no bother to me since by that time I had been living in the Castro for over a year. Then comes my server. He couldn't have been more impatient. 

"Oh, can we get the avocado from the rock and roll on the side? I'm allergic." 

"Um, let me check with the chefs. It'll probably cost extra."

"Why would it cost more? I am allergic I can't eat it. Just put what you'd put in the roll on the side."

"Let me check."

Comes back

"No, you'll have to pay."

I say "Nevermind." He leaves, I look at my friend she is sad. I run back to him. "Can you just put it in, I don't want her to not have the avocado. I'll take it out myself."

"Ok ok ok god. Is there anything else? These people are working fast you know."

Ok, wow......................

Next to me the gay couples were telling me how great their food was. They made me happy. I didn't understand. I had lived in the Castro forever and never felt weird about being young or straight or female (well weird about being young at Urban Bread, tell you about that later). Furthermore, it's not like Osaka is some big fancy pancy place. I've been to much more high end places that have treated me excellently. I just didn't get it. 

The server came back, my eyes attacked him like daggers. 

And finally at some point during the night, because I'm not the type to pretend I'm not peeved, I said to him, "You know sir I don't appreciate you making me think that I'm being a fuss because I'm allergic to something." I think he apologized, can't remember, but I knew he knew he'd fucked up. 

And the sushi? Did I care at that point? Not really, and to be honest it really wasn't all that great, especially for the price. Sushi Time is relatively close, and the service and atmosphere there are excellent and unpretentious. I'd rather get slapped than go here again, and quite frankly I hope you get slapped if you go here after reading this (Ok I'm totally kidding, I'm not THAT aggressive).
author: Alexandra M.

description:
BOYCOTT: After visiting Osaka on Castro for 6 years straight, my friends and I finally had enough recent bad experiences to write a negative review about it. The service is slow in general, but during our last visit, back in early 2007, our waitress admittedly forgot to place our entree/sushi order! After we said that we wanted to cancel the order, she stated that we can get it to go, but we still have to pay for it. The skimpy 10% discount she slipped into the bill did NOT suffice.  

This is very poor restaurant policy, and apparently this has sparked a string of bad reviews for Osaka. We switched to the sushi restaurants in Noe Valley instead.  It's only a few blocks away!

Total Osaka revenue lost by my boycott so far: $4,600. Ouch.
author: Daniel C.

description:
A great place to go with friends and drink vats and vats of unfiltered sake and Sapporo beer.
As far as the sushi - go for their specialty rolls. I like the power of love roll  - shrimp, cucumber, mango and cream cheese tempura fried and covered in sweet mango sauce - the forever young roll - white and read tuna with green tobiko - and the Castro fire bomb - I don't know what's in it, but its hot as hell.
My pick for sushi in the gay ghetto.
author: Jamie M.

description:
Came into Osaka today with a group of friends for a late lunch. I wasn't too hungry, having eaten breakfast maybe 3 hours before, but ordered a simple Philli roll and Shiitake Maki. A couple girls got basic bento boxes, another got the Delicious roll, and the bf had the tempura roll. 

I can't speak to their food, but mine was ok. The Philli roll is my favorite thing to get, but I think the ones I regularly get at Safeway are of the same quality-- and more for your money. I ordered the shiitake roll after falling in love with it at Domo, and was very disappointed. As much as I love mushrooms, this tasted funny and I had to soak it in soy sauce.

For comparison, I asked the bf what he thought and he said he'd give it 2 stars. His edamame was old and flavorless, and the tempura roll was "cheap, so that was good, but the quality wasn't that great."
author: Emilia S.

description:
Lunch box is a deal, their fresh oyster app is so very very good (decent size, good value, tangy "juice").  Me and my eating pal have made this a regular lunch stop before working our mid-shifts.  Very fast, very consistent.  Recommend the tempura over the ebi tempura roll.  The breaded and fried chicken is good but the teriaki salmon is awesome!

UPDATE:

Oysters have been milky - meaning BAD, while the price has gone up.  In general, the sushi tastes less fresh, the prices are slightly higher during lunch than last year, and we miss our adorable blonde geeky gay waiter.  We're done with Osaka.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I had been here once before for lunch and it was perfectly decent but nothing memorable.

My sweet angel and I were catching a movie at the Castro and had a little over a half hour to grab some food and get to the movie. We jumped in here, ordered immediately, and were brought our food pretty quickly. No nonsense, no hassle servers.

I was really impressed with my Tempura Udon. A huge bowl of piping hot broth, noodles, and all kinds of veggies, tempura crunchies, scallions, etc. My tempura was served nice and crispy on the side. Very satisfiying and flavorful due to the addition of all those tasty veggies.

We were in and out, got to our movie right on time, and we were nice and full! Thanks Osaka! I'd come back for that udon!
author: Audrey K.

description:
I am giving this two stars because I honestly think you can get cheaper and better sushi somewhere else. Like Sushi Time or Sushi Zone. 

I think its very overpriced for what it is. I don't think it makes sense to charge $16 for seaweed udon. What a rip off. I also agree with Rocky K. that 12 bucks for an avocado roll is extremely overpriced. 

Staff is friendly....ambiance is OK, not great. Location is good only because its in the Castro. 

I don't understand why people give this place 5 stars for sub par Americanized sushi. 

Will never go there again.
author: Patrick C.

description: On a Friday night after work, a coworker introduced me to this gem in the friendliest part of the city. I know I'm not the best person to say that one sushi place is better than another, but this place is good. It is a bit pricey, but that's because of its location. I'd go here again.
author: Theresa D.

description:
maybe its the fact that my friend and I have had a ritual for many years that included sake+several tall beers+TONS of sushi that makes me LOVE LOVE LOVE this place...

or, it could simply be the fact that the sushi here is DELISH!

if you're in castro, eat here....sooooo frickin good

the pink lady roll, volcano roll and crunch n' munch all rock.
author: D G.

description:
I'm kind of the luckiest guy in the world. Why? Because this sushi place is the closest sushi restaurant to my apartment. Which means I have no excuse to NOT eat here when I'm craving some maki or sashimi. And man, does this place deliver. 

Their rolls are super fresh and tasty. Their specials are creative and always worth trying. When I come here with friends, we usually split a Bento Box and order a few rolls and you have to roll us home. No pun intended. Okay, maybe a little pun. Whoops, I did it again. 

The prices are slightly higher than average, but it's worth the cost. And if you come here and try the food and feel the additional cost isn't worth the value, I will pay you the difference.*




*Don't believe a word the author says when it comes to money. He's cheap and will not pay you the difference.
author: Jared S.

description:
A little too expensive for such mediocre sushi. Also: sometimes I've gone and had to cope with awful smells wafting in from the bathroom, kitchen or some other place. 

I do like the concept of their bento boxes, though. It's nice to be able to piece a meal together like they let you.
author: Tyler S.

description:
I have been going to Osaka Sushi for years.  It is, bar-none, my favorite sushi place in the City.  The sushi is always fresh.  They fish selection is fantastic.  The rolls are delicious and creative.  The service is great.  

Hell, I've watched them serve up live spider crabs as the little guys scurried right off the cutting board and into the deep fryer.  Not my cup-o-tea, but no doubt they're fresh when they're movin'!

Note, I'm allergic to avocado and I love that they don't stuff avocado into every single roll they do!
author: Amy A.

description:
I like Osaka and I am not a big fan of the sushi.
They have a huge assortment of vegetarian fare, not just sushi.
Other japanese restaurants with their measly browning avocado rolls take note. 
The staff is always friendly, the place is open late and the food always come at you quick.
author: Sean S.

description:
It's really sad when an old favorite turns out to have gone down hill.  We used to love Osaka Sushi and were really excited about going Saturday night.  Everything was a disappointment.  The two rolls we ordered were so spicy we could hardly eat them.  Not a little spicy, way too spicy.  The agedashidofu was awful.

Like I said, it's sad when one of your favorites goes bad, but we will not be eating there again.
author: Sean O.

description: This place had some yummy sushi.  While not the best in the world it was great sushi prior to my bar hopping.  The site is a bit worn out and tweet cramped.  While not the best service in the world it was good enough to get the job done.
author: Jonathon S.

description:
Yum!
 
Good deal- good sushi- if you like the different types of rolls. I went with some friends. I ordered a bento box-dinner- not nearly as neat or good as the sushi plates- they gave a very good portion too and it was much better than the bento dinners. 

Luckily they actually gave us a lot so there was plenty to share around!
author: oth k.

description: This place is always awesome. Never have had to wait, even with a party of 6 people one time and they are always fairly quick with the food.
