Ordering edamame as an appetizer only takes 1-2 minutes for it to appear in front of you, so you have something to nibble on while you wait the 10 minutes for the sushi to appear. The staff is always on-top of refilling your water and never felt pressured to leave as we waited for the rain to let up. Will be back.
author: Matt H.

description:
Let's not mince words: I heart me some sushi.  In fact, if I was forced to choose only one cuisine to eat for the rest of my life, hands down, it would be Japanese.  No question.

Osaka on Castro gets two stars from me and that's being sliiiiightly generous.  

I came here for the first time with a girlfriend before catching a flick at the Castro Theatre and we only had about a half hour to spare before the show.  Well... the hot tea and edamame that we ordered to start our meal never came.  [Okay, fair enough, I'm easy, and I had a show to get to.]  Add to that, the rolls and nigiri we ordered weren't anything memorable.  Add to THAT, when our bill finally came, it included the missing edamame and hot tea.  So not only did we NOT get the items we ordered, we got charged for 'em.  [Hmmmm... something's amiss here...]

While our waitress was able to rectify the bill, I doubt I will come back, for there are just too many other damn good sushi joints in this city where I'd rather spend my money.  Sorry, Osaka!  I wanted to like you, honest!
author: Katie C.

description:
I used to make weekly trips from the fog packed area that is SFSU to Osaka just for some sushi. I now live in Boston, but always try to make it back there when I visit. While it isn't anything special like Blowfish, it does make some pretty good rolls for a semi reasonable price. I loove the power of love roll...shrimp, mango, cucumber and cream cheese with a mango sauce. If you are in the mood to share a dish...or just be a pig and eat it all...the Roll Combo Entree is great. 3 rolls(California, spicy tuna and rock'n'roll) with miso soup. The sake is always good too. Mmmm

However, the one roll I have had here and would not recommend is the Gangster Roll. Its a HUGE roll with everything under the sun in it. It was topped with salmon and i think tuna, and on top of that black and red tobiko. I could not eat the whole thing. It was fish overload. Still good, but just too  much going on.
author: Spencer N.

description:
After All Season Sushi down the street burnt down (or whatever happened. it doesn't really matter, it re-opened again) I decided to satisfy my veggie tempura craving here.

They have a Lunch Box special which consists of two items off of a little list (veggie tempura, teriyaki chicken, sashimi, etc.), miso soup, rice, and salad for $9.50. I always get the tempura (obviously) and tofu teriyaki. The tofu thing is pretty interesting. Its two little rectangles of semi-firm tofu with this funky gel-like, possibly fried, outer skin with teriyaki sauce. I had to try it twice before deciding whether I liked it or not. I do.

Their sushi, which I have not tried, seems to be on the more expensive end of things. I think this is a good place to go for the lunch or dinner box specials, they're decently priced, and you get a nice little variety of flavors. They also seems to have an interesting selection of sake, and offer "flight samplers" for around $11.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
While running errands and a fresh influx of cash, I thought I would treat myself to some fish while in the Castro.  How often does that happen in the Castro?  Teeheehee  :-P

Seriously, I've been here before months ago and had good memories of Osaka's sushi and figured this is as good a place as any. 

It was mid-afternoon, so plenty of seats.  One thing about this place is it's variety.  Different kinds of sushi that is not common.  That's great.  Where it snags is in the pricing and taste.  That $12 sushi roll didn't taste like a twelve dollar sushi roll.  Nothing special at all.  And for the pricing, I expected a little more quantity.

I think on a busy night, it would be a good date place.  The service is good too.  Otherwise, there are equally and better choices in the City.
author: R G.

description:
Its in a convenient location. Their prices are reasonable & the service is pretty good. 

My favorite has to be their seaweed salad. OMG so good! 

As a person allergic to fish, they do a good job of having other yummy stuff on the menu, like tempura & teriyaki bowls. 

Plus they're open later than most other sushi places.
author: Rebekah K.

description:
Randomly walked into this place last night since they seemed like one of the best alternatives to burritos after 10pm.  Overall, I thought the food was pretty good, excellent chicken karaage, good range and execution of the veggie tempura, standard miso, bleh salad drenched dressing, but holy wtf on the spicy tuna roll!  I don't usually order the the spicy tuna roll, but grew up fishing in hawaii, so I like to think I know what different types of fish are supposed to taste like . . . and this was umm . . . no.  no good at all.  It almost tasted like the tuna had sat in an unlined tin can packed with squid guts for about a year, then mixed with a lot of mayo and spice in hopes of covering up the nastiness.  

Bad fish . . . okay I can deal with that, but when mentioned to the waitress that the fish might be bad, she said, "Oh when people say that, we tell them that it's just the sauce.  We can make it again, but it'll taste the same."  Umm, no thanks, I'll stick with the chicken.  For an $18 dinner bento I'd expect any response other than that.  Oh well, seems like they get that a lot with their spicy tuna roll . . . wish I had read yelp first.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
This is a fairly decent sushi ya.  I like the layout and decor, even if it is a little small.  I'm not overly fond of the prices here, but they are fair for sushi in San Francisco.  I go here when I'm craving something a little different, something healthier I should say, when I'm on Castro.  I'm starting to enjoy polishing off happy hour with a maki or two.  

If you're in the area and want sushi, it's a good bet.  It's, however, not a place you'd go to that's out of your way unfortunately.
author: Brent A.

description:
Honestly I used to like here..Food was ok.service was terrible.I arrived here at 10pm for eating sushi.
We ordered some plates included Nigiri combination,they came very quickly and looked good.but there was no Nigiri; that's why I asked waitress about it and showed
her Menu and plate.she said "you ordered Roll comb,this is your food".I said I ordered Nigiri one,,she said"you said Roll and pointed roll,if you wanna order new one you can".I was struck dumb by her behavior.I thought how rude she was..coz when she was taking my order,her hand was on table and she was yawning yawn without cover.
She seemed it was not my false.however sushi chef who looked Korean,he cut her bad talk and told me" I'll make your food right now.he was very nice till last.
When Nigiri was ready,she called another waiter and told him"I don't wanna see them,bring it..therefore we weren't enjoying to eat it.she was tidying table and bringing chairs up on table..then chef improved our mood again!!
When I got receipt,it didn't revise.I told waiter about it.he said we're not gonna take extra,if you wanna pay it you can.hahaha 
Why do customers and chef have to be attentive for her?If this was provided by Japanese owner,it would be second rate perhaps,I mean customer service
Only sushi chef was nice to us.star for him.I wish our tips went to that nice chef!!
author: S V.

description: Cheap happy hour specials (oysters and rolls). Pleasant service. Cozy.
author: Inigo M.

description: A little overpriced.  Not the best sushi in SF, but it's ok.  If you live close to Osaka you will grow to love it.  I usually go for the lunch special.  It's a bit pricey for a lunch special at just under $10, but it's pretty good.  I usually get tempura and sashimi as my choices.  And to drink I usualy get a cup of green tea and a glass of water.  I wouldn't travel from far to eat at Osaka, but if I was in the Castro at lunchtime and I wanted Japanese food, then I would go there.  I honestly ate at Osaka about 100 times, so I guess I must like it.  However I just can't give them 5 stars because they don't deserve it.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Apparently I have a big ass huge mouth.  It is sooo big that I can be likened to a wide mouth bass or other related fish with a huge mouth.  My mouth is sooo big that it is on par with Kathy Griffith. 

This, is the only thing I can conclude after witnesses the girth of the sushi rolls and sashimi at this joint.  I mean, wow, they must have really noticed how big my mouth was, like big enough to stuff a roll the size of a McDonald's cheeseburger in my mouth. 

Aside from the daunting size (my dining companion declared she just "couldn't shove another one of those in her mouth.") the sushi was very average.  It wasn't bad, but wasn't really good, it was just a bunch of really huge sushi.  

So I guess what I'm saying is that you are in the mood for average sushi and are an Ogre, this is your place.
author: Claire C.

description: We wandered into this place while sight-seeing on vacation.  We started with the stuffed eggplant, which is four portions of two pieces of eggplant stuffed with spicy tuna and then fried in a tempura batter.  Delicious!  I followed it up with the Ginza roll.  It had a very strange, almost flower-y taste.  I was not a fan.  I did, however, love the spicy crunchy roll that came with salmon.  Delicious!  It's a little overpriced and the service was spotty, but provides a pretty solid lunch.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Cute sushi restaurant in the Castro. They have a full menu, but I've only gone here for sushi. I like their big selection for specialty rolls, I get to try something different each time.

Some of my favorites (so far!) are: 
- Gangstar Roll: spicy tuna, hamachi and salmon with spicy masago
- Geisha Roll: spicy tuna topped with white tuna
- Sake Maki: salmon and green onion
- Kamlkaze: yellowtail and green onion
- Rock'n Roll: eel, avocado, cucumber

They have an expensive selection of sake, so we usually go with the hot house sake and it's very good. 

I also like their green tea ice cream! It's very delicious! YUM!
author: Gladys C.

description:
There are a lot of better sushi places in the city but Osaka does deserve a nod for being the best sushi place we've found yet in the Castro (where every other restaurant I've eaten at, save my beloved Tallulah, RIP, has TOTALLY sucked).

Fish is fresh and we did have a really good roll with maguro, hamachi, albacore, and cucumber wrapped in soy paper.  It doesn't get us excited but it does satisfy our fix without disappointing and it's not terribly expensive.
author: Jenny S.

description:
You pay a pretty high premium for location at Osaka.  As the food is mediocre and portions meager, this makes for a very poor value.  Take some time to wander and eat elsewhere!!!

Some examples:  Spicy tuna roll was mediocre.   Service was as well.  Softshell crab was a fortune and miniscule. Rainbow roll lacked substance and had meager portions of fish.

Had to over order to get a decent meal.  $100 dinner for two- NOT AGAIN!!!
author: Anthony G.

description:
Eh.  Meh.  I'll get sushi here if it's Monday and my favorite sushi place (Sushi Rapture) isn't open.  The sushi is average, the wasabi not very hot, and what you get doesn't always match the way it's described on the menu.  

Not a big deal if you don't care, but I have a severe shellfish allergy.  Last time I ordered a Castro Bomb, which the menu describes as "tempura fried unagi with tobiko wrapped in avocado with chopped oranges and spicy sauce."  So why was there a freaking shrimp in there?  Luckily my boyfriend noticed before I took a big bite of death.  They were nice about getting us a new one, but come on, give me what I ordered in the first place.
author: Lizabeth S.

description:
I came here a few times with ex a while ago and wasn't overly impressed. But I recalled seeing a GIANT platter of tempura that I filed away in my head as something to indulge in one day.  That day arrived a month or so ago. I needed a platter of deep fried stuff.
Went there and found it was HH. Oh boy! Instead of GIANT platter of tempura for $$, I opted for 2 appetizer plates of tempura for $. And some sushi.
I don't remember what HH sushi I got. Maybe a CA roll and some nigiri. It wasn't great. It was passable. The fact that I can't remember means it was "meh" but not "ugh!"  I think I recall the CA roll being very mayonaisse-y.
The tempura, however, was not so good. At all. Thick, hard batter, too greasy, not salty enough, and overall lacked flavor. MInd you. I still ate it all, but that's because I always eat everything unless it' truly disgusting.
But I was very disappointed. The sauce stuff it came with was nothing more than soy sauce. I love Nara's accompanying tempura sauce- it's sweet and salty with a kick of something. But this? No. Pure liquid salt. It needed some sweet  to bring out some kind of flavor in the tempura, but no. While it's true the tempura lacked salt, the liquid salt sauce did not help.
All in all, a big, fat regret.  All that grease consumed for little enjoyment. Too bad.
Even the tempura at Barracuda's all you can lunch is better. I'll go back there for lunch and order many servings next time I'm craving plates of breaded, fried veggies.

EDIT months later:  I just found a picture I took of my 2 servings of tempura. Who cares, right? But I want to post pics! Ooooh! Look! Pics!
author: Allucaneat G.

description:
I adore this restaurant.  Great sushi - I would venture to say imaginative sushi - at great prices.  Service is always very friendly even though the interior and tables are rather bland and outdated.

When you're trying to eat before a night on the Castro, this is the place to go!
author: Michael D.

description: Non-traditional crazy roll type of place. Had the Osaka roll (soft shell crab and other goodness) and tried other rolls ordered by others. Not bad, not amazing. Someone in our party said uni is the guacamole of the sea. (!)
author: Maximillian M.

description: Service has improved since my last review. The Dragon Roll is luscious. I prefer Sashimi to Sushi to avoid all the filling rice and starch. The fish is fresh. They serve it in rather large chunks while I prefer the thinner slices I have had elsewhere. Next time I will request it that way.
author: Lee S.

description: I love this place, and I've never had a bad meal here. From the appetizers, to the sushi and entrees it's all delicious.GO HERE
author: Lauren V.

description:
They have discriminatory hiring practices! Hiring only Asian people is as bad as hiring only white people or only straight people. And it's in the Castro where discrimination is generally not appreciated. If a non-Asian knows Japanese cuisine, sushi, has worked in Japanese restaurants, lived in Japan, and speaks Japanese, why be racist?

I'll never eat there again.
author: Cindy C.

description:
The last several dinners I've had here have been excellent with no decline in food quality nor portion size. I usually order the bento box with sushi and salmon or chicken--both excellent choices.

Recently tried the bento box with a calamari steak which was superb--much like abalone.

Food here is extremely fresh and artfully prepared, so easily rates 5 stars. The service is very friendly and efficient, too. Osaka Sushi is a neighborhood gem.
author: IQuack D.

description:
My favorite sushi place period.

Pros: Their specialties, their huge selection, fast, prompt service, japanese sushi chefs

Cons: price? although by the time i got to eating, i forgot about the price.

I admit that I like americanized sushi.  The BF and I are big fans of maki fans and gastronomic innovations.  But I have to say that my first time here was an unforgettable experience, as they say.

During my first time with a friend, we ordered the Tropical Napoleon (a castle of rice, fish and grapes I think) and other sushi rolls with fruit.  I had been amazed that sushi could have fruit (mango, grape, etc.) and nearly ordered all of them.  I loved the combination of the sweet and the taste raw fish can only have.  Even though it was small sliver of fruit, it was...so exciting.

I don't know how we finished two rolls and the Tropical Napoleon, but I loved it.

During my second time with the BF, we ordered the Osaka Fantasy, a spicy special roll (which I don't remember the name of), and Yakiniku sizzling plate. The Osaka Fantasy was simply the sushi inards inside an egg crepe.  I appreciated the creativity, but it just simply tasted like sushi within an egg crepe.  I am not sure, but it could have been executed better for a better complexity of tastes.

And I have to say, the spicy special roll was...so spicy.  I normally can't take too much spice but I usually try around the BF.  This time, I couldn't speak for nearly 5 minutes while I let the waves of "heat" rush through me.  But I was super glad that the BF loved the fact that he could taste the spiceness...although he didn't like the fact that I was so affected.  The sizzling plate was enjoyable, but not outstanding.

I take no stars away, because my first time was the best.  Even though my second time wasn't...I still can't wait to go back.

The servers poured tea promptly without question.

Plus it's on Castro right near lots of action.  The second time we went on the Saturday before Halloween and the restaurant was filled with interesting characters.
author: Jenn N.

description: This seems to be the place to go after a show at Castro theater.  On the smaller side for seating and waiting area.  On the higher side for prices.  Menu seems to have a decent selection except with vegetarian options, but my teriyaki tofu was very nicely made and a good filling portion (which is a problem with eating at sushi places) so no complaints there.  If you aren't too picky about finding the perfect place and this is convenient (and isn't full) give it a try.
author: Pat L.

description: Just coz you're in the heart of Castro, doesn't mean you're that good. 3 star goes to your acceptable food. What annoyed me was how we were being rushed out just coz you're closing. Rude. What's worse, I was already in a bad mood that night.
author: Rika P.

description:
Let's see. First, service. At no point did the waiter bring us any utensils or chopsticks. This dude wanted us to eat with our hands so badly, it was ridiculous. Nothing at the beginning when we sat down and no spoon after I got my soup, even after we asked politely.  We gave up and just walked over and got them ourself from the counter. Then when my friend had some special requests, she was subjected to eyerolls and sighs. I know the special requests can be a drag but either do them or don't do them, kay?

I ordered a chicken katsu box and the chicken was old, hard and brown. Bleh. My friend got her custom roll and another roll that had like, rice krispies on it. I forget the actual name, but Rice Krispy Roll was so spicy that it burnt our lips off and made our eyes tear. All you could taste was red hot misery, which was only deepened when we received a hefty bill for such a crappy experience.
author: jessica s.

description: I wouldn't say it's exceptional or that the space is great, but the sushi was fresh and just what we wanted. The rolls coming out looked amazing. I like to sit at the bar and watch them make it, but this bar is kind of small and the place is busy.
author: Helen K.

description:
This is my new fave neighborhood sushi joint for two reasons:
1.  It's pretty cheap
2.  I can get there via 1 bus (which means I can have all the saki I can hold)

The food was good - not the best I've ever had, but worth it.  The people working there were extremely nice!
author: Charlene E.

description: Since I moved back to the city, I haven't really found a GREAT sushi bar. Then I was in the Castro and decided to try this sushi spot for the first time, and OMG!!!! It was so delicious! For those who like sushi, just not the raw stuff, I'd recommend trying the Nor Cal Roll! It's crab, eel, wrapped in seaweed and sticky rice, deep fried in tempura batter. Topped with a spicy chipotle sauce and caviar. It's an amazing tasty shock to your tastebuds! My only problem is they took FOREVER!!! I get impatient when I'm hungry... Lol
author: Shai W.

description:
Setting aside all the hipsters, the noisy drunk crowd, and the slightly elevated prices, this place has consistently been the best sushi I've had in the city. These guys know what they're doing, and they have fun doing it.

Not just for the fish lovers. People of all paletes will find something good to eat here.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
Been eating at Osaka about 8 years now and recommend them for good sushi. The sushi is always fresh and tasty. When the owner or the long-time chefs are there, they really go all out with big fat chunks of fish on the specialty rolls. The "Castro roll" is an excellent mix of sushi on a roll. They actually did away with it for awhile but it was so popular they finally brought it back! 

Very comfortable and cozy, especially since the put the booths in. The wait service can be lacking at times but still within reason.  The prices aren't cheap but again within reason for sushi.
author: Moby D.

description: Really good!!!!   Great happy hour, awesome sushi, friendly service, great location..  4.5 stars     I really like the place!    Will be going back many many times!
author: Blake S.

description: A really nice sushi place right in the middle of the Castro. Pleasant service. Good food.
author: Nobbi L.

description: I might try this again and sit at the sushi bar but honestly not my fav place. I know I can go to Miyagi and have great service and pretty darn good simply sushi. Or I can go to blowfish and have super fancy rolls and moderate service. OR I can go to my new fav sushi place in the hood...all seasons. The rolls at all seasons are far more creative and interesting and it was a lot less fishy. The service at Osaka was just okay, nothing to write yelp about. ;)
author: Nikki M.

description:
Went to Osaka Sushi on Saturday with a friend.  She's allergic to, pretty much everything and anything with gum.  So, Sushi was the main and easy option.  Castro is always lively so you may have to wait a bit if you go on a Saturday but, fortunately, for us, we were seated right away.  Right next to the kitchen and a couple steps away from the bathroom but, hey, whatever.  

The food was actually pretty good, I have to say.  I had the San Francisco Fire and stuffed eggplant.  I didn't think it would be a lot but it sure was.  My friend had healthiest rolls on the menu.  Poor thing, she couldn't even try my food.  Bummer.  No matter, it was good times and the bathroom was quite clean too (sorry, to me, that matters).  The service was decent and I would definitely return to Osaka if I'm craving that stuffed eggplant!
author: Dorothy S.

description: Let me tell you a story about one drunken night... uh well lets not I can't remember it anyway. I know we ended up here. I have lived in the area for a year now and I am kinda surprised I never stopped here for sushi. Being the sushiholic that I am that puzzles me a bit too. Anyway, the Sushi was really good and fresh. The service was excellent and I have no idea how much we spent. I did fire off a couple shots with the cellphone camera of the yumminess we consumed. Honestly I was not that toasted so I do remember it being the perfect late evening dinner. I will return. Sober next time so I can remember what I ate. :-)
author: Nichole S.

description: If you want to have a good japaneese food, just go elsewhere. Since I was not starving, and just wanted some light, I ordered a sunomono - seaweed and cucumber salad with prawn - but I was not expecting, that for 11 dollars I get a small plate, with 6 slices of tasteless cucumber, a few dry salatleaves and 3 icecold prawn.   Nice. Since I was not full, I tried my friends food too - the teryaki salmon was overcooked and dry, the beef was chewy, and so on. I never wanna get back to this place!
author: Nora N.

description: Great Food and a Wide Selection of Specialty Rolls. Very Nice!
author: Rix G.

description:
We went on a Friday night, seemingly right before the rush.  The sushi was good, fresh and tasty.  Nice big glasses of water (much appreciated, since 1 of the rolls we ordered was SPICY).  I like and appreciate their specialty rolls; I'm allergic to shellfish so sometimes have a hard time finding a good roll that doesn't have crab or shrimp or something in it.

We splurged on dessert too.  Deep fried azuki red bean ice cream balls!  SO DELICIOUSLY WONDERFUL!
author: diana s.

description:
The bento box was a bit pricey $18.00.  Salad had great dressing, miso soup was good, but I found the tempura lacking.  

I'd recommend getting the Yakiniku (sliced rib-eye steak), sauteed with with mushrooms and onions - great flavor!
author: Corey C.

description:
There does seem to be something ultimately "ick" about their Spicy Tuna Roll.

It's not everyday I can convince my picky American friend Boo to eat out Asian.  He'd eat sammich's for every meal if he could, but on one random ocassion, when we found ourselves shopping on the Castro this past Sunday, he let me choose and we ended up at Osaka.

I can't complain.  My meal was pretty good.  A Bento for a decent price.  For $10 I got 5 pieces of fresh sashimi (Sake and Maguro), edamame, miso, salad, ebi tembura roll and sushi rice.

I left the salad alone but pretty much housed everything else.

Boo got the bento, but with the 2 rolls his picky pallate actually likes, the harmless California Roll and the popular Spicy Tuna roll.

He took one look at the spicy tuna roll and pointed at it.  He gestured for me to look at it.

"Ummm..what IS that?"

"The spicy sauce.  It's usually mayo based."

"Why does it LOOK like that?"

I didn't have an answer for him.  After trying a piece, it's like the minced the tuna really fine and drowned it in orange mayo.  The spice factor killed any taste of fish whatsoever.

My meal was pretty good and I was satisfied, but forewarning, if you're with a picky non-sushi eater...

no one order the spicy tuna.
author: Jen I.

description:
Tried Osaka the other night, and was satisfied, but not impressed, or dare I say WOWed.  

Things I liked - casual atmosphere, mostly couples dining, prompt service, reasonable prices, great miso soup.

Things I didn't like - too much rice in the rolls, the secret "crunchy mix" which isn't more than rice crispies and orange mayonnaise dumped over your roll.

That's it, more pros than cons, but... if I'm going to eat, and the food wasn't that amazing, I'll likely pass on Osaka to try something else.
author: Alice H.

description: Had a very nice lunch here today.   My server was very nice and attentive.  The hamachi was perfect in texture, rich in flavor; tako was from my favorite part the meaty section of the leg with suckers; aji was tender deliciousness dressed traditionally; red dragon roll was spicy and complex and a nice counterpoint to the sweet fishes; the uni was the star obviously locally caught still smelling of salty brine, smooth succulent, slow melt uni, a delight to savor long on the tongue like chocolate.  They played lovely cocktail piano in the background.  Sort of incongruous with sushi from one perspective but pleasant nonetheless.   And a clean bathroom to boot.   I'll be back for more.
author: Russell D.

description:
A  run-of-the-mill sushi joint in the heart of the Castro, capital of run-of-the-mill restaurants.  The service is downright horrible.  I asked my waiter what kind of oysters they used in one of their prepared oyster dishes.  He told me he didn't know and then stood there as if that was acceptable.  I had to ask him to go to the kitchen and find out what kind of oyster they used.  Other waiters I've encountered have no clue what's on their menu, or no opinion about anything on it, as if they were hired that morning from an IHOP and weren't sure what Osaka's cuisine was.

Sushi chefs are friendly and efficient enough, but in the two times I've been there, they figured toro prominently on their whiteboard, but were out of it.  How about erasing toro from the whiteboard if you don't have it?  Easy enough, eh?

The cutting technique is unremarkable.  I say this only because I ALWAYS remember how fish is cut at Eiji or Takara, but I can't recall how it's cut at Osaka.  I don't remember being impressed overall, and found the whole experience too pricey for the lousy service I received.
author: Andrew L.

description: Great lunch box deals and happy hour specials.  Friendly staff.
author: West P.

description:
Lord, can you throw anymore rice on your rolls....

So here is my pet peeve, just about every sushi restaurant reviews composite score is nearly 4 stars.  Is sushi so exotic that it is just all good all the time?

This restaurant fails in several respect:
-- No hot towel service (big no-no)
-- Rolls are like so huge and saucy it reminded me of eating Chicken Fingers....where the sauce is the goal versus the actual fish
-- Cheap plastic dishes
-- too much rice baby....and it was nearly the same consistency of rice you would find at a Chinese restaurant...

This is McSushi at best.
author: Laurence H.

description:
What a delight this place was!

The sashimi salmon was really tasty and fresh. Yum!! That's more than I can say for most sushi restaurants in the bay area. 

Their house rolls are delicious also. They were better than most places I've had in the city. I recommend the Power of Love roll. It's a fried roll with avocado, mango, cream cheese and unagi inside. It made my taste buds go wild.

The spicy salmon was also quite good.
author: Pete C.

description:
If you're looking for sushi in the castro, this place is reasonably priced for the quality which is both good and consistent.  I've eaten here dozens of times and have never had anything bad. 

Hint: if you want a selection of sahimi with a tasty salad for a lil' less than the platter that only comes with rice, order the seafood salad.
author: Nikke G.

description: Two stars only because they were open after 10:30pm. I was thoroughly disappointed with the power of love, crazy spicy roll, and oysters. My friend's udon was good tho.
author: Jillian O.

description: The place is cramped but they have really good food and service. I got the avocado roll and the vegetable tempura roll. Both were great, especially the tempura roll. They have a good selection for vegetarians.
author: Melissa S.

description: Favorite sushi place in SF.  Good prices and friendly service.  The Gangsta Roll is the best.
author: S B.

description:
You may have to wait for a table if you come in during the evening, especially the weekends, however, the reason why i took off a point is because i was disappointed when i came in for sushi during lunch, not that great...

The first time and the most recent visit was really good!! Maybe because it was during dinner time?? Anyway, i love their salmon teriyaki dinner, never have i had salmon teriyaki on a sizzling plate over a bed of onions, red and green bell peppers, it was sooo sooo good!! Mmmm! Their soft shell crab appetizer is sooooooo good along with their sauce!!! They are much bigger and meater than the one at Ebisu.. Sushi is great during dinner time, skeptical about lunch though..
author: Karen F.

description:
If you're in the Castro on a Wednesday night after playing some basketball and are craving sushi, you should definitely go to Osaka Sushi!  Well that's what a friend and I did.  Not being from the area, we definitely had no idea that we would find good sushi in the Castro.

The Hamachi Nigiri just melted in our mouths and the rolls that we had were just as delicious - Gheisha and Gangsta rolls.  I guess another plus was that we asked them to change the channel so that we could watch the Warriors beat the Celtics!  

I would definitely come back again and enjoy the great sushi!
author: Christine C.

description:
There sushi is really good, and fresh, but this place is all about service.  The employees are all so friendly, and make sure that you receive everyhting exactly as you order it in a timely matter, making this place a "can't beat" in the drunken gay night on the town circuit.  I love to eat here to soak up some of my liqour halfway through my night, and possibly ad in some more...that is if I'm feeling Saki that night.  All in all, this is a pretty damn good Sushi Restaurant!

xoxo
author: Joshiwa L.

description: Yuck, yuck, and even more yuck! The Unagi is not fresh. It always tastes very spiny. They use too much rice in their sushi and not enough fish. The service is terrible. Sometimes you will go in and there will be one person working or there will be more employees then customers. I think this place is way over rated!
author: Ryan M.

description:
Not very good, not horrible but not good.
I had the smoke salmon nigiri and have had many different vegetable rolls-- not impressed.
author: Ashe M.

description:
A typical Japanese restaurant.  Good sushi and tasty sake.  I dined with a party of 3 and although the bill was a bit expensive, I guess the prices are reasonable for late business hours.

Added bonus: entertainment on the Castro.  It's never a dull moment in this district.
author: Anne K.

description:
Sniffle.

This used to be a great place.

Its on the downhill.  It used to be not so busy, the rolls were unique and the ingredients quality.

Now, its busy, the rolls seem stale, and the quality of the ingredients, questionable.

best pick: Lunch bento box, its all I would get from here now.
author: Ken p.

description:
I love this place for its great sushi and excellent sashimi.  The raw fish there is super fresh.  Other than Ebisu (Inner Sunset), this place is serves some of the best sushi and sashimi dishes in the city (and you don't have to wait half-a-day to get seated).  

The size of the sushi and sashimi pieces are also very generous.  When I order sashimi at other places, I sometimes get these little slivers of fish that resembles carpaccio more than sashimi.  The rolls and specialties at Osaka are also very creative and they change daily.

Other specialties that I would recommend are their Hamachi collar (the collar bone of the yellow tail tuna).  They bake it with a little lemon, salt and pepper.  You get a big piece for about $8.  It can be a dinner in itself with a bowl of rice.  To foodies, that's the best meat on the fish.  For those carbo-phobic, they have a great lobster roll appetizer.  It's lobster salad rolled in cucumber and served with orange fish eggs and a great dressing. 

The reason I give it only 4 stars is because their service could improve.  It's not that they don't try, but rather, their wait staff seems to forget things a lot.  Every time I go, they will forget a dish or the check for example.  You may have to ask for things twice.  I have learned to order the appetizers and salads first and then dinner separately to get around this.  Other than that, the service is fine and the wait staff is very friendly.  The food come fast and you never have to wait for a seat there if you go before 7:00 for parties of 4 or less.  My motto is if the food is good enough, I will sacrifice some service.  Osaka's food is for me definitely in that category.

If you want to look at their website, it is:

http://www.osakacastro.com/
author: Oliver S.

description:
So i can't say that i loved the place, but i can say it was decent. I wanted a specific sushi roll that was made with soy paper and without seaweed rice, and they were very accommodating.  Hints the three stars other than that, it the tempura that was in my roll was kind of cold and the shrimp tempura portion of it was totally burnt.

The customer service was...well..it just was. i can't say it was terrible nor can i say it was great. I do know that it took the waiter kind of a longtime to take our order, but he was very good on refilling our waters..i suppose that should count for something.

i can say that i enjoyed the unfiltered sake i had, i don't know how to spell so i'll just won't. Anyyhow my friend, that i tends to make me try everything suggested i try it and i liked it.

all and all it was cool, i enjoyed it...but like i said, i can't say that i loved it!
author: Nia W.

description:
The crunch & munch roll is more munch than crunch, but I can't complain about any of the other rolls I've tried - I love it all!

Last time I was here we ordered the fried calamari and my dining companion was pleased because he "likes the head."  Girl, this ain't that kind of restaurant!
author: Marcus C.

description:
I used to live in Noe Valley, and would wander down to the Castro for clothes shopping every now and then (Noe boutiques are just for women).

One day after a couple hours of browsing around, I popped into Osaka for a lunch box. It was great! Friendly service, good vegetarian options, and a giant bottle of Asahi topped things off. I called over the waitress when I was done and asked for the bill. That's when she said...

"Oh that's okay sir. The gentleman over there has already taken care of your bill."

I am a skinny and fairly effeminate guy in his twenties. I was hanging out in the Castro. But I am straight. What do you do in this situation?

I turned around and a guy that looked a lot like me smiled and waved. I walked over to his table...

Me: "Um, hey thanks so much for the offer. But I couldn't. I'm not really into guys."

Him: "It's just lunch. It's my pleasure."

Me: "Um, no sorry. But thanks a lot!"

I called back the waitress and paid cash and left. I felt kind of confused as to whether or not I had done the proper thing. I passed on the story the next day to a couple of my gay co-workers... One of them told me I was being presumptuous that this guy was hitting on me (come on!), and the other told me I should have just taken the free lunch and high-tailed it out of there.

What should I have done? I mean, I didn't want to take advantage of this guy, nor did I want to have to sit around and flirt with him.

Oh, you Castro!
author: Trey F.

description:
At every sushi place I go, I order the spicy tuna roll. Because each sushi chef makes it uniquely, I find it a good barometer of how good the sushi place overall is (although I really shouldn't...).

Yesterday, Osaka served me one of the worst spicy tuna rolls I've ever had in recent memory. Sucks. 

But their lunch box is under $10 and you get a LOT of food. I was full for the rest of the day throughout the next morning, too. You get two entrees, rice, miso soup, green tea, and salad. Great bang for the buck. Go for it, just don't eat the spicy tuna roll.
author: Adam S.

description:
Escolar is my new favorite food. It tastes like BUTTA!

We had a craving for sushi and Osaka just happened to be around the corner from the neighborhood bar we were at (review on its way) 

We had the chef's fresh platter and were not disappointed. Great variety along with our friendly Korean server made this sushi experience one of my favorite to date!

Spicy tuna roll is a staple favorite of mine and this place delivered. Looking forward to my next visit to SF to come back!
author: Tyler J.

description: Another great place that I've been to multiple times.  Good service, yummy food (tempura, sushi rolls, etc.), good times!  I don't really remember anything specifically off the menu, but I personally love Unagi and I know I've tried one of their Unagi rolls and it was delicious.  Prices are good/standard.  You won't spend an arm and a leg, that's for sure, and you'll definitely get a good meal out of it.
author: Beth H.

description:
Ah, my favorite sushi place in town. This place seems to be consistently good with a friendly staff and I have been dropping in here pretty much once a month over the last few years. Very fresh and tender fish along with a pretty yummy miso soup as well. On most visits the tuna was melt-in-your-mouth. I've only had one issue (language barrier) and that was when a new employee delivered a plate of 'Mackerel' instead of 'Maguro' but that was quickly deducted off the bill by one of the regular staff and I appreciate that. Lunch specials are pretty reasonably price and of good value. A couple of times when it was busy they really needed an extra staff member to avoid slow service which will turn some first time visitors off. Look on the chalk board for a large variety of 'specials' - some very creative.

I'm giving this place 4 stars although there is not much room for improvement in this great little slice of the Castro.
author: Bobby J.

description: I go here at least once a week (yes I am addicted to Sushi), I have the lunch bento box and it is consistently fabulous.
author: Target T.

description: I find the sushi to be good and service is always welcoming when I go here.  I agree with other reviews the prices could be a little lower.  Considering this is in a good area in Castro, you will pay a little more for food at most places there.
author: gayle w.

description: Service was great, but what I ordered was just too chewy for what it was supposed to be. Didn't think it was super fresh and usually sushi should be. Great beer specials and a cute place!
author: James V.

description:
I didn't like sushi for a really long time.  Slowly, over the past few years, it's grown me.  I've had some here and there, and I now like it.

Since I went to Osaka, I love it.

I went twice in one week after my first time trying it.  I've tried several different rolls, my favorite being the spicy crispy fried kind that I can't name right now.  But really, of all the ones I've had, they're delicious.  The staff is nice, the chefs will chat while they do their art, and it's close to home.  New favorite.
author: Nate R.

description: Just because there was a sign that says this restaurant is supporting gay marriages does not mean, all the gays have to come in and eat in here, The food was terrible and overpriced. esp the service, one of the waitress did not really do her job, not even asked u how things are after the meal is served.
author: Daniel S.

description:
went here after a little happy hour time. . .the more i think about the more i was kind of to put it best disappointed, this place ive seen for years and ive been to a couple of times but i guess this time since i was really observing it wasnt fantastic.

i had my usual order calamari, which to me wasnt all that great. it didnt have that chewy consistency that i like with my calamari nor does the batter all that great.

we also got a plate of the gyoza, fried, and it was good but then again you cant really mess up this dish. fried just right and decent filling.

the last thing that i got was the gangsta roll which contains hamachi, cucumber, green onions covered with unagi & salmon topped by two kinds of colorful tobiko & unagi sauce. to me the roll itself was alright nothing really memorable even though most of the ingredients are my favorite in sushi.

overall i said not worth the money for the food here. the service was ok not mind blowing so that makes it even less appealing for me to come back or to recommend to anybody.
author: Tofer M.

description:
Friendly staff. Convenient location if you are on your way out to bars on the stro...

Their rolls are a bit haphazardly prepared though. Although they are tasty, they are hard to eat since they are not wrapped well and too large...

I have been there more than once. The last time I was there their UNI did not taste good at all...

Oz
author: Oz O.

description:
The rolls here are HUGE! lol

Overall, it is OKAY. My friend got sick after eating here. It's always crowded, especially for dinner.  They're kinda pricey but hey, it is in the Castro - everything is a little higher than most places. Try to go a little early so you can get a table by the window. 

Good Sake.
author: Charlage W.

description:
i wont go there again
the service i recieved was good
the food not so much
for the price of the rolls there should be a little more sushi
also one of the rolls kind of smelled a bit off 

i ate my 2 rolls and was left a little hungry
author: Trent D.

description: The food was good. Uni was fresh as well. Their server made a mistake on my tab and had the guts to lecture me in front of everyone. I had an order of sashimi uni.. finished it and ordered "specifically the same thing" from another server. When the tab came uni prices were different so I asked why and this server comes up to me and insists that I made a mistake and was not clear to her about what I ordered. so she lectures and lectures.. Oh well! I am not going back. To make the long story short, Servers are not very well coordinated and what happened to be their little mis-communication was POINTED at me.
author: Patty P.

description: Mmmmmm, so full after an unagi roll, spicy scallop, and some salmon sashimi.  Spicy scallop roll wasn't even on the menu, but they made it for me anyway.  Only thing lacking was they didn't have real wasabi.  No sushi place can get 5 stars without real wasabi.
author: Kevin V.

description: I love this place...  I know it's a Sister Restaurant of Barracuda, but I tend to like their selection better than the other.  The food is excellent and the prices are fairly affordable.  Great place to go to for happy hour before going out later or just during the week casually.
author: Brian C.

description:
Teriyaki Chicken was excellent. I have yet to try their sushi. 
I am very picky about my sushi. Will put more information on my next trip.
author: Sam D.

description: I have been here a few times during happy hour 4pm to 6pm and think it is a great value. The happy hour menu has plenty of choices, the beers are $2.50 and warm sake is $2. It is a nice place for a snack or early dinner. The service was normal speed, not too fast or too slow and the place was not crowded.
author: Kendall W.

description:
Quick service.  Good food.  Nice presentation.  Comfortable environment.  Music not my style but fine.

Bento with chicken teriyaki and gyoza: very good chicken, grilled, juicy; nice tasting gyoza, delicate wrapper.  Simple rice with a few toasted sesame.  Iceberg carrot salad: good tasting mayonnaise dressing.  Pickled cabbage was nice.  Miso soup was good, some sweetness, the tofu had a bitter taste. 

Tried some of the tuna poke and rainbow roll dishes, easy to eat.  Greens, seaweed, and pickled shredded things of tuna poke were good.  Roll was fine.
author: N R.

description: Fresh and good.  Super happy hour deals... great service too.  I ran into friends eating here, which is always a good sign.  The Chirashi is one of the best versions of this dish I've had.  I have gone to Barracuda, which is owned by the same people, but I think this location is better and less hyped.
author: Aaron W.

description:
This isn't Kaiseki Ryori by any means, but as a seemingly real Osaka food house it succeeds.  The Bento lunches are a great deal and authentically fresh Kansai cuisine. 
Added bonus for a laid-back, attractive, attentive & mixed staff.  Some Japanese joints can have overly stern masters making the rolls and clouding the atmosphere.  Not here.  The chefs are of age, pros, and OK with The Castro's gay bustle.  It's a nice mix of skills and a relaxed izakaya vibe.
author: Dean V.

description: This is an awesome sushi restaurant!  The sushi is fresh and top quality and they have a large selection of awesome rolls!  The Gangsta and the Castro Rolls are two of my favorites.  The staff is friendly, attentive and fast.  I have not been disappointed by anything I have ordered in the 10+ times I have dined there.  Parking can be difficult, but it is worth the effort!
author: Sandra M.

description: This is my favorite Castro sushi joint. The staff is as great as the food. I love the rolls (especially the Super Fire roll), bento boxes and their selection of sake. My friends and I visit often and they seem to always find space for us. Check it out!
author: Eric M.

description:
I like this Sushi place because it is convenient due to it being open all day. Most sushi places close around 2pm, so if I am out and about I always have to factor this in to when I am going to stop for lunch. But not with Osaka. 
This isn't blow your mind sushi, it's more of a nice neighborhood type spot, and the prices reflect that. But the sushi I have had here (generally my sushi lunch staple of seaweed salad, sake sashimi and a dragon roll) have all been good for the price. 
Despite it being right in the Castro, I have never had too much of a problem finding parking during mid-afternoon weekdays, which is when I would recommend coming here.
author: Helena P.

description: The best part of this place is location. There are some other good spots, The seating is crowded and a favorite with the locals. Not world class, nor the best in the Castro. Special menu items are the on the high side but some of the standard rolls are priced well. Service could be a bit friendlier.
author: Joe R.

description:
are you into those unconventional, uncustomary sushi rolls??? that according to some prolific yelpers it is also known as jive ass rolls???

well if you are...OSAKA on castro is the MUST place for you to indulge on those sexy, hot, gorgeous sushi rolls!

creatively done & sufficiently stuffed with tasty fresh fish and imitation crab, crunchy veggies AND nicely topped with roe and with their very own spicy, creamy sauces as well as the standard teriyaki sauce.......
i would say you could have a grand orgasmic experience and still being "chaste" after you have a savor of that wonderful piece of maki.

such favorites of mine are the RED DRAGON ROLL (big pieces of deep-fried unagi, shrimp tempura, cucumber & spicy tuna, topped with a spicy red sauce & teriyaki sauce)
SPICY CRUNCH ROLL (very fun to eat and quite intersting because of the rice crispies on top. it has shrimp & imitation crabmeat with spicy masago, and of course, the usual TEMPURA ROLL that everybody adores (or maybe not) (pleasingly filled with crunchy shrimp, green beans, asparagus & kabocha).

the agedashi tofu are average, they put little bonito flakes and green onions..and yeah, less sauce too. i'm used to MORE! also, the gyoza are mediocre. the waitress will ask you how would you like it cook...sounds like you are ordering a piece of steak...the options are boiled, deep-fried and pan-fried. i opted with pan-fried. i want it like that.

these preferred rolls & appetizers are enjoyed usually in my cherished tight corner area by the front, facing the glass window & the busy street.

the menu are jam-packed of fascinating, invention by the sushi chef. it has too much to choose from that you need quite sometime to decide on what to order.

moreover, TRADITIONAL nigiri and sashimi can be ordered for those who are conformist to a customary japanese fare. their bento boxes are also awesome with excellent choices to have as your "two different items."

the waitstaff and chefs are very competent.

open late, it is a suitable restaurant to have your late dinner or snack.
author: Nelle A.

description:
I give the food 5 stars and the service a 2.

In fact I'd give the food even higher marks if I could.
A friend brought me here about a year or so ago and it is my absolute favorite sushi. 

The servers come to you to order even when you're clearly still checking the menu. Something I don't appreciate is that they don't clear used/dirty plates from your table at all until you're gone. i really think it's appropriate to have your diners enjoy a free uncluttered table rather than bus the table once after service. And how hard should it be to get a water refill, especially if your eating something spicy. (Yes I know, water doesn't alleviate spicy food but we all have our ways about us).

As for the food, the best way I can describe it is, put one bite in your mouth and your eyes'll roll to the back of your head. The different textures combine with an unfolding of flavors that hits your tongue and palate.

This is as close to orgasmic as you can get food-wise without being a chocolate mousse! It makes you wonder if Willy Wonka learned his gobstopper idea from this sushi chef!

I've tried several of their dishes including their edamame, spinach goma-ae, dragon roll, red dragon roll, power of love, etc.

If you like things creamy with a bit of heat, Red Dragon Roll... all the way!

Best sushi in town with service that could learn a thing or two from the ladies at the nail salon across the street!
author: mike r.

description:
We went to Osaka tonight. Sushi didn't come over half an hour. The cute waiter came and apologized. Actually, he was saying sorry to other tables as well.  We were sitting on the booth.  Spanish music from kitchen was loud.  It was annoying to hear too different music when waiting for food long time. The waiter asked sushi chef to make faster for us. Then, Sushi chef was saying different table number and gave us sushi. The waiter picked it up before I grab it. He said sorry with embarrass.  Finally, sushi chef himself admit that he was drank. No wonder. F**k we were waiting for half an hour like other irritated customer. 
Employee shouldn't drink.  Of course Sushi wasn't good either.  
There were new servers. Whatever we asked, answer was I don't know. Look like they don't know what they are doing.  
I wouldn't go back there. 
Pretty  Suck.
author: Bryan s.

description: Definitely under-average sushi place.  Everything was about average, nothing stood out special to me.  We ordered a $30 bottle of Sake which was also average.  The salad with octopus was OK, the Octopus was tasty but the salad was bland.  The rolls are HUGE so don't order too many.  We ordered a few pieces of Nigiri and it was edible but nothing special.   I made the mistake of ordering a roll with Shiso which I despise, so that was my mistake.
author: Mitch A.

description: I had an hour to kill in between setting up at the Castro Theater and setting up the after party. I was very happy that they were open for lunch. I mainly ordered specials. Tuna, aji, baby lobster and a phily roll. I was in the mood for salmon for some reason. The service was friendly and relaxed. The fish was very fresh. Food came pretty quick. It was a very relaxing lunch/dinner that got me through a rough 20 hour day.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I have to write a review for Osaka because I have probably eaten here 100 times, at least. This is where my business partner and I meet for our business lunches at least once a month, if not once a week. Osaka is a fantastic place to go for lunch!! I love it here, even if the sushi is not my favorite. I usually only eat nigiri but here I eat the rolls and that's because it's great to split them with Diane. If we go early we each get the bento box (cheap and good) and if we go at 4:30pm or later we do "happy hour" where they are practically giving the rolls away. It's, I don't know, $3.50 or something super inexpensive like that per roll. For early lunch we get out spending $12-$15 each and for happy hour we spend $8 - $10 each. They have some really fun and elaborate rolls too. I just love it here for the price and the convenience even if the fish isn't my favorite. The atmosphere isn't bad either, sitting by the window affords a really fun time!!!
author: Kimberly H.

description: My girlfriend and I visited before catching Singin' In The Rain at the Castro Theatre, we were a little surprised at how long it took us to get our orders taken and to pay the check. When my girlfriend ordered some miso soup, they didn't bring her a spoon until we got our rolls, a bit frustrating in terms of service. I would give three stars, but when it took nearly twenty minutes from finishing our food to get the bill. Decent sushi, low-end service.
author: Taylor S.

description: DE-licious! We ordered the Rainbow, Spicy Cowboy, and one with eel in it and they were all fantastic! Reasonable prices, good sauces but drenching the fish which was tasty. The Spicy Cowboy was actually too spicy for my date ;) but I loved it. Highly recommend that roll and this place.
author: Jocie M.

description: really good sushi, great for lunch.  Sit at the sushi bar or window seats if you can.  Great rolls too.
author: Pug P.

description: Tasty sushi rolls, delicious fired calamari, excellent service. Went there with my husband for some late lunch sushi, they get busy, a lot of people sitting by them selves, sign that locals stop by for a meal, good sign. They happy hour is good deal, cheap beers and sake and some special rolls and appetizers at great price.
author: Ma B.

description: Some friends recommended this place to me, and it's right down the street from my new place, so I gave it a try and was not disappointed! The service was very good and friendly, the sushi was VERY, very fresh, it was a Thursday night and no wait for a table, and the bill came to $27 for two (with hot saki and two orders of rolls each). I'll be back soon!
author: beth l.

description: The ngiri was reasonably fresh, but not the best I've had in the city.  I didn't care for the rock 'n roll - there wasn't a whole lot of eel, and they poured the sauce on over the entire roll instead of on the eel, wtf.  Nevertheless, plus 1 star for the service.  The waitress was very nice and offered to move me to another table when she noticed the open door was making me cold.  Wish more servers would be so attentive and observant!
author: Leslie L.

description: Not great, not bad. The only reason to go would be for the happy hour prices. Decent wait staff.
author: Erin D.

description: Their oysters are great, both the raw and the ones that are smothered in some wonderful sauce.  The bento boxes are also wonderful, big huge portions,  and always enought to fill me up.  The tempura is always good, so is the salmon.  Sometimes its kinda crowded, but the staff is always nice to you.
author: Janet R.

description: Service - uneven. Food - ditto. There's too many places in the same 'hood that so a much better job with sushi to waste your $$$ here.
author: Rene D.

description: Hardly edible? I think not...The sushi is excellent! This is some of the freshest sushi in town! This is coming from someone who has been a fan of that no-name sushi place on Church for years...I know good sushi when I have it! Yes, it is a little more expensive than other sushi, so be prepared to throw down an easy $30-$40 for two people. But, I'm paranoid about fish being fresh...and this definitely is!
author: Nick M.

description: Mediocre sushi for a decidedly above-average price. They do offer a good assortment of yuppie-style rolls, which admittedly appeals to me. However, the quality of the fish never quite seems as up to par with other places, even some in the Castro. Yet another place in the Castro I'll never pick on my own but go to, begrudgingly, when that hot guy I met at the Bar wants to grab a bite. Walk the extra few blocks and go to Amasia on Noe instead. Cheaper, tastier, better.
author: Aaron L.

description: For the food and the ambiance this place provides, I think it is way too overpriced. It is nice to see actual Japanese sushi chefs instead of the now more common Chinese, Korean, or Latino(!) rolling and making sushi. The rolls are decent, but man, how much can some fish, rice, and avocado really cost? 12 bucks for a roll with 8 pieces is a bit too rich for my blood. It does make for a nice place to have some, again overpriced hot sake (from a box!), and beers before stumbling over to another place in the Castro for more drinks.
author: Rocky K.

description: I love Osaka and have been coming here for years.  Good quality fish.  A decent, albeit packed, atmosphere.  Fun and interesting rolls.  A little pricey, but for good sushi it is always worth it.  Get in for the happy hour deals and it won't break the bank. Go for the Toro!  The wait staff has to go.  It has been getting progressively worse over time.  I would have given it four stars otherwise.
author: mika m.

description: The location is great.  It's easy to find, and at that time, it was very close to the salon I worked at.  I was the new girl in town, and where I'm from, we have really good sushi.  I needed a quick sushi fix, and decided on Osaka (I usually go to Daly City, but didn't feel like driving.)  It wasn't bad, but I think for that price, I should've gotten at least a little more sashimi.  Their miso soup was horrible, like it came straight from those packaged soups. I don't know...I don't live in the City anymore, but I'd definitely recommend going elsewhere....
author: I M.

description: This is one of those reliable sushi places. When you're hungry, craving sushi, or just happen to be walking by and have an urge, Osaka is a great place. One of my best friends is now a sushi FREAK, where she's getting to that sushi snob kind of status, and she eats here. The service is great. Food always good. and its in the Castro. How could they go wrong.
author: Mama Jaz C.

description: I think they have some of the best soup and noodles I've had and for that reason alone I give it 5 stars.  I've only had sushi there once, but it all tasted good to me that day.  It's an enjoyable place to lunch.
author: Jenn M.

description: I went here yesterday, and it wasn't bad. I would give it 3 1/2 stars but, the chef was nice. It was hard to get the waiter staff's attention. It was kind of busy but still. The food was good but, not awesome. I'm kind of a sushi snob since I've had one of the best in Sac. =P But if you do decide to go to Osaka, get the delicious roll thin cut! it was Guud!
author: Kissy F.

description: When visiting San Francisco a few times a year, we usually stop in for a Bento box a few times during our trip.  The atmosphere is a little loud, but the quality and quantity are excellent for the price.  The menu is diverse.  It's a great place for a casual bite.
author: Brent R.

description: Overpriced for mediocre sushi. And since the service was erratic, well, just not a great place.
author: K F.

description: Visited this place for the first time with my friend Jill, who had gone before and loved it. We ordered the Power of Love roll - cute name & great taste! I loved the sweet taste of mango with the tangy smoothness of the cream cheese, combined with unagi and shrimp. DELICIOUS! And the presentation was absolutely gorgeous. High marks are well deserved for this special roll! In addition to delicious food, we were seated quickly (even though it was a weekend) and the service was friendly and responsive. I will definitely go back the next time I'm craving sushi in the Castro!
author: Rachelle A.

description: I'll give props to the person who coined it "gay ghetto sushi".  Price wise very reasonable and a great variety of rolls and assorted sushi right in the heart of the Castro.  I'll give it an extra star because the meal started out with a bellyaching laugh when a muscular gay man cruising Castro drove by blasting and getting down to "Don't you wish your girlfriend was hot like me"  For some reason that continued to crack me up the rest of the evening.  Back to the restaraunt review...probably wouldn't hurry back here because there are a plethora of good restaraunts over there but I would probably dine there more if I lived over that way.
author: Amy Z.

description: Not going back for a LONG TIME. Osaka has been going downhill for a while but this was the first time I could not finish my meal... BAM! 8 hours later I felt like doubling over and vomiting but could not! So I just shit my brains out for a few hours... I think this was the first time I ever got food poisoning from a restaurant. It's sad, I really liked this place too...
author: Dustin H.

description: diarrhea on 2 separate visits back to back after 5 minutes of leaving the restaurant, also $13 to $14 for nigiri toro, not good
author: N A.

description: Not your traditional Japanese sushi restaurant, more like an Americanized sushi bar with a Castro twist. They offer a decent selection of sashimi, incredibly creative appetizers and rolls (the Delicious roll really is quite amazing), and solid nigiri and maki sushi fare. The cooked food is consistently satisfying, although the bento box can be expensive during dinner hours, but is a deal at lunch.
author: Suepattra M.

description: i used to love this place. but not so much now. the (newer...?) waiter staff seems to never seems to have their stuff together. the food is good, and the guys behind the counter are delightful, sure, they are probably the few bright spots about this place. but going back to the wait staff. just terrible. the last 2 times just left a sour taste in my mouth.
author: Mike A.

description:
I'd give them 3 1/2 stars, but yelp won't let me blah blah blah.

Overall, I thought the food at Osaka Sushi were decent, good enough for me to go back there on purpose. The server was polite and brought us our food in a reasonable amount of time. Rolls were decently sized (I personally like the rolls to be on the big side, just so I feel like I'm getting more for my buck). The atmosphere wasn't bad, but the music they were playing was nearly the worst shit I've heard in a sushi restaurant in a long time.

After 7 different rolls and 1 seaweed salad, the bill came out to about $58. Seems about right in the city.

I also hear they had an animated "Norbit" ad in the bathroom. I'm not quite sure if I should rate them lower or higher for that.
author: Alexis C.

description: I've only tried the rolls and the sake during happy hour and they're all great.  If you're in the Castro and have an urge for sushi; this is the place.
author: Lauren F.

description: We've been here a bunch of times.  The sushi is decent.  Good.  Boyfriend likes the chicken katsu.  The restaurant is decor is interesting and kinda like a castle.  The music is horrible, some kind of Japanese flute that sounds out of tune to Western ears.
author: shannone e.

description: Been here a few times so far and have been thoroughly impressed each time.  The fish is always fresh and tasty, their sushi rice is perfect, and if you're into bastaridzed American sushi their rolls can be pretty amazing (try the "Louisiana hot link roll" if you're not a sushi snob, it's fantastic).   They also seem to be pretty good at tako (octopus) as it's NEVER too chewy here.  Not really sure how they do that...  While not a high end sushi joint, you could do a LOT worse in this town for a laid back place to have some tasty sushi.
author: Joshua W.

description: My friend Ramiro asked me to come out for lunchies aroun Castro. We were going to No Name Sushi, then we found out it was closed. Then we went to Nirvana on Castro and it was also closed. So after two strike, we decided just to go somewhere that was sure open; hence Osaka Sushi. I have not been here for few years. I used to come visit and got some hamachi kama or all of the interesting names sushi rolls they had. Anyway, my bf came too... he is Japanese, so he is usually kinda picky about sushi, but today he wasn't. We each had the ten bucks bento box. I had the sashimi and salmon teriyaki (I am watching my figure...). They were good, good portions, and good price. The girl who served us was nice and CUTE! I mean she was just pretty charming and plain nice. Good lunchies... especially when your friend treated you... darn, that means next one is my treat...
author: dannydan d.

description: Seems like Japanese food is hard to come by on Saturday afternoons...but Osaka was open and I was happy to try something new.  Pretty solid Lunch special bento boxes, generous portions, and fresh sashimi.  Friendly service as well, my green tea cup was always full :).
author: Debbie Y.

description: Osaka is basically solid.  The service is friendly, but forgetful.  Twice or three times we've ordered something that never showed up and needed to be re-requested, but our issues were addressed quickly.  The sushi is fresh and tasty, but a bit pricey, and due to the Castro location, there is frequently a wait.  Basically, if you come in the afternoon and order something relatively simple, you'll have a great experience.
author: Jude F.

description: Admittedly, I have been slow to warm to Osaka during my SF visits and during the decade I lived in the city. Was it the crowd and wait for tables? I went there with four other guys on May 16 and we were promptly seated despite the otherwise apparent wait. I ordered the bento box and two hand rolls (yes, I was hungry, we'd been doing TKD), and split three small carafes of sake with one of the guys. The food was delicious and arrived at our table in good time.
author: Jim G.

description: Good for a neighborhood sushi joint...big, elaborate rolls and fun waiters (ok, at least Brandon is fun).  Fish quality isn't really anywhere near the best you'll find in this city, so stick with the rolls rather than sashimi unless the sushi chef can tell you when and how the fish is that day.
author: Michelle P.

description: This is my place.  This was the place where I fell in love with my future fiancee.  Then, my brother and his girl took me to All Season Sushi down the street... howevah, the rest is NOT history.  I will still go to Osaka and not just for sentimental reasons.  The quality of mid-priced sushi is going down lately, but Osaka has held it's own.  In any sushi restaurant, you should always cruise by the sushi bar and LOOK at the fish-- that's why it's on display people!-- before taking a seat and committing.  I've never felt compelled to leave Osaka.  All of the standard rolls are good; they always have tons of creative special rolls; the staff are nice; it's right on Castro and it's open late.  I also like their Udon, but I would eat Udon all day if I could.  A safe bet for Sushi in the Castro, especially the yummy bento lunches.  They also have sake flights!
author: E L.

description: Rolls were tasty and very creative.  For example, deep fried tuna, avocado and salmon roll, no rice.  The warm, crispy goodness of the pankow-crusted outside gave way to still-cool, delicious bites of fish on the inside.  Sushi chefs are a little wierd in that they won't take your order "when it's busy," but they will cheers you and share beer with you, which is always a plus.  Decor is nothing to write Yelp about.
author: Aaron F.

description: A sushi bar.  It's been there for a while, haven't ever tried it till now.  Large seating at the bar, several tables too.  Delicious and fresh fish for sure, and a few dishes on the menu that seemed out of the ordinary.  Not any more expensive than one might expect a sushi restaurant in the Castro to be.
author: Ken B.

description: Osaka is one of my lunch time spots. I usually can get in and out of here quickly with good service and good food. They've got a great lunch box deal for $9.50 that include miso soup, salad, rice, edamame, and 2 others entrees of your choice (off their selected list). Sometimes I splurge and go for one of their delicious special rolls which are huge and impossible to eat. Don't order this on a first date because it doesn't fit in your mouth in one piece, and well, I usually end making a mess of the beautiful roll. But oh so delicious.
author: Lindsay A.

description: As much as i go to this place i'm still giving it 3 stars. Why do you ask? well i still recall the night i went and was pretty smashed. I had ordered the Hamachi Sashimi and the fish was still frozen. that was not good whatsoever! eh! Their service is meh but it all depends who you get!
author: Lucky M.

description: There is better sushi to be found in town, but if you're in the Castro, this place does the trick.  It is a good location, and they do have an interesting selection of rolls at decent prices.
author: Tim G.

description: Osaka is okay, but in a city where you can get Japanese anywhere, you can get better. The sushi is nothing special, though they do have a good selection. But, the rolls I had weren't really put together very well. They also seem to be perpetually understaffed, so service gets spotty at times.
author: Barn M.

description: I used to live upstairs from this place. The sushi is hardly edible!! And overpriced. But good if you're desperate.
author: Cate F.

description: I'm a little surprised by some of the reviews below because I love this place and go there often with my love or friends.  The wait staff are always incredibly nice and competent.  The food is always consistent and fresh.  And some of their special rolls are simply divine.  The Power of Love roll is just creative goodness - of course, not "traditional Japanese sushi," but good food nonetheless.  It's right in the heart of the Castro and is open relatively late, so it's perfect for that pre- or post-going out meal.  Although it's a little pricey, if you mix special rolls with the regular menu, it comes out being reasonably priced.  Never had appetizers, beyond edemame and seaweed salad, though, so I can't speak to that.  Oh, and the hot sake is good.
author: Anya L.

description: I like this place. The layout and the decor are nice and the food pretty good. I suggest the Geisha Roll, one of my favourites. The service was very good. The only drawback is that the place is pretty small and there are not many tables. Even though dining along the bar is nice
author: Steve E.

description: My friend had some of the rolls here and, wow, they were huge! The portions here are decent for a Japanese restaurant, especially when it comes to the sushi. I had the tempura udon, which was very generous on the tempura side. The menu has a lot of great choices, but I was disappointed to see that a lot of things were only offered on the lunch menu. It's as if they post the lunch menu with the dinner menu just to torture me. I hate it when that happens.
author: Kristen R.

description: I've been here twice in the last month and both experiences were great. I think with Osaka it really depends on the day that you go in terms of fish freshness (can be a little inconsistent but so can most sushi places). They have a great happy hour special with different rolls, tempura and gyoza for half off. You also can get really cheap sake and beer specials. The second time was the charm: ordered the calamari (very small portion tho), dragon roll and the crazy roll. The dragon roll was the clear winner, the crazy roll was pretty bland and I could not distinguish between the three fish in it. The rolls are really good and the fish is usually fresh for the most part (the unagi can be a little mushy, but it is cooked so I'm not really surprised either). They also have daily specials of different fish from Hawaii and other parts of the world. It's not cheap, but if you're looking for something new to try it is worth it. The service was ok, I really think it depends on how many people are there...if it's busy the service gets scant (there's only two waitresses working there so what can you expect?).  The bento boxes are a good deal too!
author: Gina R.

description: I live high above Castro in Twin Peaks so this restaurant is super convenient and very yummy! I almost always go here for lunch as I'm not one to hang out in the Castro much at night. There's almost never a wait, the service is always decent, good prices and very fresh sushi. Lunch box special ($9) comes with miso soup, salad and choice of 2 items.
author: Paul H.

description: Stopped in here on a crazy-hot day for a late lunch.  I sat at the sushi bar and ordered some nigiri and a hand roll.  Overall, the sushi was decent.  Fairly fresh tasting, good texture, but not great.  I also thought it was a little pricey for what it was.  I ordered the hamachi nigiri, saba nigiri, unagi nigiri and a tuna handroll (7 pieces of sushi, all together), and the bill came to about $26.  It's a decent place to stop for a bite, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go there.
author: Michelle A.

description: pretty good sushi, skewers were a bit dry, but you can't go too wrong with meat on a stick.  nice place.  A-OK, as 3 stars indicate.
author: regina k.

description: When you have literally one night in San Francisco and you want to take your husband to the Castro so he can see it. (He has never been) and he is craving sushi you end up asking someone from one of the stores "Where do you go for Sushi?" -- this is where you end up. My husband I eat Sushi all the time. We would probably eat it every day if we could. We wanted to go someplace nice since it was our only dinner in SF. We walked in and it was so crowded but we thought... a crowd says something about the place. We enjoyed it very much. It was great food. It was expensive to us (and we live in Washington DC... no cheap eats place) but it was a special occasion. We were not aware the portions where larger then usual so by the end we were stuffed. We really had a lovely time. The only complaint was the table next us. The guy sitting there was very loud and annoying. He went on and on about how hot he was (a model... for what? the before shots?). It is not Osaka's fault at ALL but we wanted to mention this as you are sitting very close to one another.
author: Jon R.

description: Okay service, pretty good calamari teriyaki, mediocre sashimi.
author: Jan M.

description: I think this place is one of the best in the city. The fish is always fresh. Unlike some places in Japantown. Great prices. Some very unique rolls created by Sushi chef Shige-san. The power of love roll is awesome. The place is usually packed, but what do you expect, It's on Castro. Service is excellent.   Quality stuff!!!
author: L K.

description: The best freakin' sushi on the planet!  Seriously, I'm sure there is better sushi somewhere...but I have yet to find it.  It's not just the variety, quality and quantity, but also the great service and atmosphere.  I've taken many people to this sushi spot and they have all loved it as much as I do.  Order some hot saki to go with your food and you'll love it even more! :p
author: Scott S.

description: The sushi was "decent", but the service was very poor. I couldn't decide between the "Chicken" and "Tofu" Teriyaki, so i asked for the Chicken Teriyaki and asked if they could add in some Tofu [and i would pay extra of course]. Our waiter made this disgusting face and acted like I was requesting something that was way out of line. "Tofu w/ Chicken Teriyaki!!" he said? I explained they had both in the menu, and after being degraded enough by his comments and gross faces, i said "Fine, I'll just have the chicken". Needless to say, my chicken Teriyaki was completely burnt and not very good. It took us at least 20 min. just to get the check. I won't be coming back again.
author: Sandra D.

description: Because i don't live very far from Osaka Sushi, i decided to give it a try despite many negative reviews.  I'm not a sushi connoisseur but i've had a fair amount and know what i like.   I had a VERY nice dinner there tonight.  I ordered the combination plate (chef's choice) and it was wonderful.  The miso was really yummy too!  The service was wonderful.  Very attentive.  They even had a cute young chef (Charles) that was nice to look at and fun to watch while i dined.   Overall an extremely positive experience.  I'll definitely go back.
author: Joseph B.
